Ottawa, August 22, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 17th instant and also requisition for certain furnishings for the teacher's residence at the Montreal Lake Indian Day School, attached thereto.

This requisition is being sent forward to the Purchasing Division and no doubt the furnishings requested will be delivered at an early date.

In this connection I feel that it is only fair to you to state that the Department has recently been subjected to criticism for the policy adopted in respect to the furnishings of teachers' residences in your district. This criticism has come to us from a representative of the Anglican Church, who informed us that it has been your policy, until recently, not to furnish teachers' residences in the agency. Quite recently, however, you requested furnishings for the Big River R.C. school. These furnishings, I notice, were authorized in a letter dated July 13, 1942. This critic seemed to resent very bitterly what he referred to as unfair discrimination or favoritism in the district. You can readily imagine how difficult it is for the Department to meet criticism of this kind. The officials are of the opinion, therefore, that the whole policy of furnishing teachers' residences in your agency should be carefully reviewed and that the greatest possible care should be exercised in sending forward requisitions for supplies or furnishings. This man, who had a lengthy interview with the Director, seemed to be fully informed on every item of the furnishings supplied at the Big River school, the man employed in the construction of the building and the general policy of the Department in that section of Saskatchewan. The Director finally suggested to him that his complaints should be outlined in writing and forwarded to the Department. He was assured that if he did this the complaints would be very carefully reviewed by the officials of this Branch.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. R. S. Davis,
Indian Agent,
Leask, Sask.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter I07-6-8 and 392-I-6 dated August 22nd, regarding the policy of furnishing teachers residence on this Agency.

I must refer you to your letter of July 3rd 1942, in which you requested that I forward a requisition for the necessary furniture for the Roman Catholic Teacherage at Big River Reserve. In this letter you also informed me that the Sisters of Providence were taking charge, and I consider that I am not to blame if any discrimination has taken place, as I only followed your instructions.

I have always tried to be fair, and as we have two schools on this Reserve, I have been careful to treat each alike, I have only changed this policy when requested to do so.

I would recommend that when a teacher is appointed for the Church of England school, the teacherage be furnished exactly the same as the Roman Catholic teacherage, and then refuse to furnish any more teacherages. If this is not done, I am afraid more criticism will result.

Yours truly,

R. S. Davis
Indian Agent.

Secretary,

Ottawa, September 12, 1948.

Re: Furnishing of Teachers' Residences.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 7th instant and note with interest the information supplied therein.

May I point out that the criticism to which I referred on August 22nd was not directed against the Department for supplying furnishings to the R. C. School on the Big River Reserve. The Government, in my experience, is seldom, if ever, criticized for the expenditure of money. The criticism was directed against us for what was alleged to be discrimination on your part, not for furnishing the teacher's residence at the Big River R. C. School, but for your refusal from time to time to purchase furniture for teachers' residences operated by other churches. It was alleged also that in the employment of men certain favours were shown. However, the critic promised to submit the whole matter to the Director in writing, and I do not know that any good purpose can be served by an interchange of correspondence on the subject at this time.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. R. S. Davis,
Indian Agent,
Leask, Sask.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES

CANADA
When visiting the Montreal Lake Indian Day School recently Reverend G.J. Waite, the teacher, brought to my attention the condition of the teacher's residence. This residence was built in 1938 and reported at that time by Dr. Robertson, then Inspector of Indian Agencies, as satisfactory. Since that time different attempts have been made to improve it but always by starting the wrong way.

Bad judgment was used in selecting the site in the first place. The classroom building is built on fairly high ground and at a good location. The residence was built at a distance of about 300 yds. from the classroom building for some reason which I am unable to explain. Where the classroom building is situated the ground is sufficiently high and well drained that a basement could have been placed beneath the building and a pipeless furnace would have made it quite warm. Instead of this the residence was erected on low-lying ground where there is water 18" below the surface. Some attempt was made to excavate a small cellar but it is always filled with water. A furnace of a kind was constructed at the rear of the building on the ground level. This furnace is an ordinary box stove with a drum above it, the whole bricked in with a complete brick wall. Two heating pipes lead from this for the purpose of heating the living room and the bedroom, a considerable distance away, through two walls. These heating pipes travel about 20 ft. horizontally with no rise whatever consequently no heat travels through them. The drum above the box stove being bricked in cannot be cleaned without removing the brickwork and it is now so full of soot and ashes that the stove cannot be used as it simply fills the house with smoke. The residence is a log building built of very heavy logs and I believe it would be a very difficult job to move it to a proper site without dismantling it and rebuilding it.

Mr. Waite is doing good work as a day school teacher and would be willing to remain at that point if he had a comfortable home. Mrs. Waite informed me that she will not live in the house another winter. The building should be dismantled and moved to higher ground near the classroom building and placed on a full sized basement with a furnace. In no other way can it be made comfortable for the long cold winters ordinarily experienced in this province. Is there any hope of this being done this year, please?

The classroom building needs.......
The classroom building needs paint and varnish throughout. The interior walls of this building are mostly of beaverboard or some similar material with the exception of approximately 3½ ft. around the base which is of V-Joint wainscoting. This is satisfactory where it has been done but the cloak-room in the back has no V-Joint wainscoting and the beaverboard which runs practically to the floor is in very poor shape evidently through being leaned against and possibly kicked occasionally by the children. It would be possible to correct this with a very small expenditure.

The main construction of this building is of logs plastered with mortar. Some of the logs have warped and twisted sufficiently to break the mortar. The whole of the building therefore needs re-plastering with mortar on the exterior between the logs. Acting Agent J. Bryce is submitting a requisition for the necessary work on the classroom building.

If anything can be done to make the residence more comfortable for the winter I would strongly recommend that some action be taken at once otherwise we will probably lose the services of one of our best day school teachers.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa, July 26th, 1945.

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
414 Federal Building, Regina, Saskatchewan.

I have your letter of the 21st instant,
with reference to the teacher's residence at the
Montreal Lake Day School and I discussed the matter
with the Director this morning.

It is noted that you consider the building
will have to be dismantled before moving it. Would
it not be possible to move this building without
dismantling it as it would involve less expenditure?

As the season is advancing, the Department
approves your making arrangements for digging the
basement and we will be prepared to purchase the new
furnace if you give us specific information as to the
type and size of the furnace required.

It has also been decided to allow you to
either move or dismantle the building on the
understanding that you will keep the cost as low as
possible. Have you any estimate on the cost of
carrying out this work?

You may arrange for the improvements you
suggest in the classroom.
The interior of the building may also be painted and varnished. The Department also approves the replastering required on the exterior between the legs.

We have not yet received the requisition from Acting Agent Bryce but the Director thought that I should write you immediately in order that the work may proceed.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

CANADA
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I visited the Montreal Lake Day School on the 6th instant in company with Mr. Bryce, the Acting Indian Agent for the Carleton Agency, to consider the question of moving the teacher's residence referred to in your letter of the 26th ultimo, No. 107-6-8.

A careful examination of the residence convinces me that it would be absolutely impossible to move it without dismantling it. It is made of very heavy logs and considerably longer than there is any need for. Because of changing the windows on one side most of the logs on that side are cut in very short lengths and would probably start to fall out if we were successful in getting the building jacked up to move it. On the other side of the building the logs have warped and twisted. These would have to be taken out and replaced in order to straighten up the wall. There is no need for a residence as long as the present one which is 40' long and 30' wide, outside measurement. A house in this country cannot be kept warm in the winter without a full sized basement to keep the floor warm. A full sized basement 30 x 40 ft. is a great deal larger than there is any need for. Nearly one third of the present house is taken up by furnace, cistern, and cupboards which should be, and will be, in the basement.

As soon as Indians are available for the excavation it will be commenced. Mr. Bryce is going to endeavour to get Adam Ahenakew of the Sandy Lake Band of Indians to perform the work of dismantling and rebuilding the house. He is a good carpenter and will perform the work satisfactorily if we are able to get him. If we are unable to get him we may have difficulty in having the work done before the cold weather sets in.

The new building will be approximately 30 ft. square with no upstairs. A pipeless furnace is required of 12,000 cubic ft. capacity, and it should be a wood burning furnace. I am enclosing the necessary requisition for this.

I would estimate the total cost of moving this building and rebuilding it on a full-sized concrete basement with a furnace will be in the neighborhood of $1,000.00...........
hood of $1,000.00. This seems like a large expenditure but it is the only way in which this residence can be made permanently comfortable in the winter. An attempt by any other means would be just a further waste of money.

The requisition in connection with painting and decorating of the classroom building at that point will be forwarded by Mr. Bryce shortly.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa, August 18, 1945.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I am in receipt of your letter of the 18th instant, No. 107-6-8, in connection with the teacher's residence at Montreal Lake Day School.

Since my visit to the Montreal Lake Day School on the 6th instant Mr. Bryce, the Acting Indian Agent, Carlton Agency, has been making many enquiries in an effort to find someone who would undertake the dismantling and rebuilding of the residence. No one seems to want the work at any price. This is the time of year when there is a great demand for casual labour in the harvest field where more money can be made than at any kind of local work. Adam Ahenakew, the Indian mentioned in my letter of the 10th instant, refuses to have anything to do with this work until after harvest this fall.

If men were available to hurry the work I would still be in favour of immediately dismantling the building and rebuilding it as suggested in my letter of the 10th instant. As there is now a great deal of doubt about the work being completed before the cold weather sets in I do not think it should be started this fall.

I would also recommend that no further action be taken in connection with the purchase of a new furnace at the present time. From further enquiries which Mr. Bryce has made and which I have made I am now doubtful that it is advisable to try to move the old building at all. If it is found advisable and more economical to build a reasonable sized cottage, of lumber, for the use of the Day School teacher at that point it is quite probable a different type of heating plant would be required, and in any case it seems that no good purpose would be served in buying a furnace until we are certain how we can make out this winter.

If a possibility arises to rush the work as suggested in my letter of the 10th instant I shall do so and advise the Department.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

On Mr. Ostrander's last visit he advised me to submit estimates for a new lumber teacherage to be built on a new site at Montreal Lake Reserve. The present house is of log construction. The logs have been so badly cut up with windows and doors, and as the bottom logs are no longer sound it would not be advisable to attempt to move this building, the labour and cost to dismantle and move the old building would go a long way towards the erection of a new lumber building.

Another difficulty is that we have been unable to get men skilled enough to dismantle and salvage the inside fittings or to undertake the dismantling and erection of a log building and replacement of new logs.

In the event of a new building being built the old building could be of more value used as a place to teach the boys vocational training, a council hall and community centre, and a place where the local Homemakers Club could gather for their activities.

J. Bryce,
Acting Indian Agent.

Further to our conversation in Prince Albert re Rev. and Mrs. Waite's house on the Montreal Lake Reserve. I visited Montreal Lake on November 4th last and am of the opinion that the floor joists at the back of the house in question have broken down. The floors and doors in the outer kitchen, the kitchen and dining room are twisted every which way.

It was decided to tear out the brick furnace arrangement in the outer kitchen to remove weight from the floor. The chimney in the outer kitchen is not built from the floor as is customary, but rests on a five foot block of wood. It would be impossible for anyone to live in the house if this chimney were torn down, however, it is anything but safe. Consequently, if the floors, partitions, etc., move many more feet, the house will definitely have to be vacated which will mean closing down the school.

I will visit Montreal Lake again as soon as possible. If I do not receive further word from Mr. Waite in the meantime, I will report on my return as to the whereabouts of the house.

Sgd. E.S. Jones,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I received a report that the day school teacher's residence at the Montreal Lake Indian Day School had suddenly become unsafe because of the floor sinking. I asked Indian Agent Mr. E.S. Jones to investigate and report to me.

Herewith is a copy of Mr. Jones' report which would indicate that the situation is rather serious.

As previously reported, this building was very badly constructed and there has been considerable correspondence between this office and the Department in connection with erecting another residence. If the house becomes unfit for habitation this winter it will be necessary for Mr. and Mrs. Waite to move out and there is no other house for them to occupy anywhere in the vicinity. The result will be that the school will have to be closed until another residence can be built.

I am writing to Mr. Jones asking him to endeavour to make the house habitable for the remainder of the winter with the hope that some better arrangement can be made next summer. If it is necessary to close the school I presume we will have to permit Mr. and Mrs. Waite to make use of the class-room building as a home for the winter as they will probably be unable to find any other place in which to live, and I have so advised Mr. Jones.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Dear Sir:-

No doubt you have had a report on the condition of the interior of the residence at Montreal Lake both from Inspector Ostrander and Indian Agent E.S. Jones. Like me they are worried about it, as to its safety. I am seriously considering getting out, before it collapses with the chimney coming down.

Before I came here, there was supposed to be a cellar, but it was full of water, and in winter it was a sheet of ice. There was a hole about 8 or 9 feet deep. I saw it before the alterations were made.

When the alterations were made, this hole was filled in with logs (some poplar logs), and earth, the floor was laid; then on top of the floor right over this hole a 2 ft. box stove was placed with an oil drum on top through which the smoke passed in one end, out the other into the stove pipes to the chimney, then the stove and drum were cased with bricks. These were taken down the other week to ease the weight off the floor. Then the chimney was built within 3 inches of the cut in the floor. There is a big log about 5 feet long with at least 16 feet of brick chimney resting on this log like this:-
Above the ceiling there is 2 feet of shavings for insulation. The floors have sagged like this. You feel you are walking down and then up; none of the inside doors will close properly, some you can put your hand through at the top at one end, the other end is tight, you can put the toe of your boot under the door posts. In places the quarter round has left the floor, at others it is on the floor with the partitions of the room two inches above the quarter round. In one room you can put your hand through and touch the outside logs, where the floor has sagged.

We have had to put blocks under one end of the kitchen stove so that my wife can cook properly. The dining room table has to be blocked up to keep it level and from running away.

Mr. Ostrander and Mr. Jones have suggested putting blocks under the chimney but I doubt if the chimney will stand the pounding and hammering.

I can assure you it is not very pleasant living under such conditions. If I have to get out you will understand the reason.

There is no living accommodation here. We are going to pack our trunks with clothes and put them in an old building so that we should not lose everything in case the chimney and floors collapse.

I am sorry to worry you about this, but think you should know my side.

Yours truly,

(Sgd) Rev. G.J. Waite.

With reference to Department letter of the 7th instant,
File No. 107-6-8 (W.T. 1), in connection with the condition of the teacher's
residence at the Montreal Lake Reserve, and letter of the Reverend G.J. Waite
on the subject, I have to say that I visited the Montreal Lake Day School on
the 13th ultimo accompanied by Indian Agent Mr. H.S. Jones. We examined the
house and discussed the matter with Mr. and Mrs. Waite.

The foundation of the chimney has sunk away considerably and I
gave instructions to have part of the back kitchen removed in order to
examine the foundation beneath the chimney with a view to temporarily bracing
it if it was found necessary. Mr. Jones had already arranged for a man to call
to do some work on it and my instructions were additional instructions to that
which had been given by Mr. Jones. I had heard nothing more and assumed that as
the result of the work having been performed the chimney had been temporarily
made safe for the remainder of the winter. This seemed to satisfy Mr. and Mrs.
Waite.

Any such work performed on the chimney or any other part of the
house is only a temporary measure for the remainder of the winter.

In conversation with Mr. Jones over the telephone today he informed
me that the foundation of the chimney has further given way with the result that
a fire was started in the roof of the house but that it was kept under control and
no serious damage resulted.

Mr. Jones is going to Montreal Lake at once to enquire further into
the matter and advise me.

I am returning herewith Mr. Waite's letter which is practically
in accordance with the facts with the exception of that part of his letter which
states:

"Mr. Ostrander and Mr. Jones have suggested putting blocks
under the chimney but I doubt if the chimney will stand
the pounding and hammering."

My instructions were that if it was found practical to do so when the wall was
removed and the base of the chimney examined wedges should be inserted in the
base of the chimney to prevent it sinking further. This would not require any
"pounding and hammering" that would be likely to further endanger the chimney
but would temporarily prevent the chimney sinking further and should have been done.
I assume from Mr. Waite's letter that he later decided against this action which
was the reason why it was not done.

The only suitable quarters available in the vicinity other than the
teacher's residence would be in the day school and that is practical only if the
school is closed for the remainder of the winter. Naturally Mr. Waite does not wish
to have to do this if it can be prevented because his salary would stop.

I wish to assure the Department that Mr. Jones and the writer have
given every possible attention to the situation at the Montreal Lake School residence
and there is nothing further which can be done until spring other than to have

Dear Sir:

I received your phone and radio messages O.K. I am having the chimney taken down.

This is what happened. About two o'clock on Saturday afternoon the chimney caught fire. I knew what it was directly. I went for help and Mrs. Waite got pails of water ready. Some one rang the school bell and in less than five minutes I had 4 or 5 men and they soon got the fire out. It burnt all round the chimney, fortunately there was no wind, plenty of snow on the roof, and daylight.

The cause of the fire was this. In October I had the chimney swept down. Apparently the chimney was O.K. but the chimney went down further. The ridge boards were wedged tightly against the chimney, for at the chimney the roof has sagged a bit. Then when the rest of the chimney went down the piece out of the roof did not go, the result the break. The man handed me down one of the bricks, no mortar, all on it. You can move the top part of the chimney with your hand. There were no braces to the other. I think the break had been there some time with the result that the cold air coming in at the break caused the soot to collect. The men moved the cook stove and medicine into the living room. Today I closed school at noon and helped my wife straighten up.

I hope to get the rest of the water out of the big tank tomorrow to save it from freezing. We have moved our perishable things in to the front room, which we can keep warm. I don't know how the other part of the house will be on very cold nights. We have filled in the holes between the kitchen and other room.

I guess we will manage.

Yours truly,

Sgd. G.J. Waite.

Where the break in the chimney is, you can lift off the bricks. I think a tin cowl should be obtained for the other chimney. It is a big chimney and the wind blows down it so much that it makes the stove pipes very dirty so soon. They need cleaning about every three weeks.

Dear Doris,

Please accept our thanks for the sacrifices they will be so useful. We are still struggling too much every day and are tired by nightfall. We had a month's holiday in July last. We drove to Winnipeg via Prince Albert, Saskatoon & Brandon. Joe & Ruth had their holiday & came to Winnipeg from Quebec to spend 10 days with us. It was nice to be with them.

I tried to get a move last year & come east, we felt we would like to be a little nearer to Joe & Ruth, especially as we are now grandparents. I tried the division of Quebec but Bishop Cameron said due to having a different pension system he could take no one over 46, so that was that. I wrote to your Bishop. He said he had a few vacant parishes which entailed a good deal of travelling, and were more fitted for a younger man. If some people could see the house we put in they would wonder how we kept going. The work seems heavier than ever. Yesterday I had my two services all in Cree - Holy communion in the morning with 104 in the congregation, evening prayer & 3 baptisms. In the afternoon with a congregation of 72 at the week I teach school. I have 58 children on the roll. This includes 9 extra ones who had to return home from Lac La Ronge (about 90 miles north) when the residential school burned to the ground about a month ago. Fortunately the fire was in daytime & all the children got out safely. I have to divide my school. I have about 30 older ones in the morning & the younger ones in the afternoon. I have 30 in grade 1. The Bishop sent me an assistant - a young Indian whom we fixed up in a small house near ours. He had finished college & would have been ordained but he left 3 weeks ago to go to a sanatorium for J.B. We live in the teacher's house. It is not an old house, but is so badly built & in such a poor place that is utterly to pieces. The Indian Dept inspector condemned it two years ago & promised to build a new house last year - but it was not done. When we came back from our holiday, we noticed the floors were beginning to sink, but nothing was done.

March 24th, 1947

Dear Mr. Percy,

Enclosed please find a copy of a letter I received from the Rev. Gilbert Watts of Montreal, Quebec, with the more personal parts deleted.

My connection & interest in this matter is the fact that Gilbert's brother Arthur married my sister.

Feeling that something should be done, I showed this letter to Bishop Jefferson. He definitely thought so too, & sent me to Dr. Alderwood, who in turn sent me to Colonel B.F. Nearly. In place of the latter, I spoke to Mr. Phelan, who, in his turn referred me to you.

I know & like Gilbert & his wife Kelly & know them both to be conscientious & earnest in their work. I was rather...
appealed to learn of what conditions are like in Montreal Lake. I would imagine that a clergyman able to preach & teach in Cree would be hard to replace & for that reason alone, should be shown consideration about living conditions. Some years ago when they were stationed at John Smith's reserve, Mrs Waite told me that the government used to allow her $40 a month for her nurses work among the Indians, but for some reason, it was cut off. She kept up the work at her own expense.

By this letter just received, it would seem that they are a long way from a doctor, & Mrs Waite's services as a nurse is surely worth considering & necessary expenses for medicines supplied.

If you feel it is beyond your province to expedite the carrying out of necessary requirements, at
Montreal Lake, do you think I could interest outsiders by having this copy of Gilbert's letter printed in "The Churchman"?

It would have a far reaching influence by so doing.

I would not do so without your permission, or unless you tell me you can do nothing in a hurry. Needless to say, Gilbert does not yet know of my activities on his behalf.

Would you be kind enough to let me know what is doing?

Yours sincerely,

Dora Haggstrom.

Dear Mrs. Hazelgrove:

I have your letter of the 18th instant enclosing copy of a letter which you received from Reverend G. Waite of Montreal Lake.

My dear Mr. Hoey:

I am so sorry that the need has arisen for me to once again bother you. I do hope you will not consider me unduly importunate, but I am deeply concerned regarding our Indian work, hence my letters.

As you know, for some two years past a house has been promised for Mr. Waite, the day school teacher at Montreal Lake, and we have been informed from time to time that a house would be built. Your Mr. Clark can give you full particulars of the deplorable condition of the present teacher's residence. This year I was greatly pleased when heard that this new residence would be definitely built this summer. Two weeks ago I was at Montreal Lake and was greatly disturbed to see that the house was not yet built, although the cement foundation had been laid. Upon inquiry, I was informed that building operations would definitely commence on October 1st, and that a pre-fabricated house would soon be erected. Mr. Waite has just been in to see me, and I very much regret to inform you that nothing has been done. The present residence is unsafe and impossible of occupation for the coming winter, and I do hope that you will take the necessary steps to see that action is taken in this matter.

I do hate to bother you with these matters, but apparently it is my only means of securing definite action. The need of this teacher's residence is most imperative.

With kindest regards,

Sincerely yours,

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 8th inst., No. 117054/1, with reference to the proposed amalgamation of the Red Pheasant and Stony day schools in this agency.

In reply I beg to say that I have just returned from a tour of these reserves, in the course of which I visited the schools, and discussed school matters with the Stony band and with individuals of Red Pheasant's band.

The Red Pheasant school as at present conducted is a signal failure. There are 12 children of school age on the reserve, besides 15 of day school age in attendance at the Battleford industrial school and 2 at the Duck Lake boarding school.

There were only 4 pupils present on the day of my visit, which is about the average for the past year.

There are 13 children of school age in the Stony band; and there were 8 present at the time of my visit.

The Crees have absolutely no objection to the amalgamation of the schools; and would appreciate the services of a properly qualified teacher, and the other advantages of an improved day school. I have good reason to believe that under such conditions a much better attendance would be had, even without conveying the children.

I had discussed the question of an amalgamation of these schools with the late Indian Agent and with Archdeacon McKay some time ago; and the Indians having heard

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
of the suggestion had been discussing it among themselves. I found the Stonies to be of one mind on the subject, and quite agreeable to their children attending a day school along with the children of Red Pheasant's. They had, however, the impression that such a school would be located somewhere near the line dividing the two reserves, there being a favourable site on the Red Pheasant's side of the line, which would be central and acceptable to both bands. But they did not express themselves as opposed to the location of the new school on a site adjoining the site of the present school if it should be deemed advisable to build there, on condition that a comfortable conveyance should be provided for the children.

I have considered the question for some time past, and have no doubt as to the advisability of amalgamating these schools; and believe that the amalgamated school can be made a success both as to attendance and results.

As to the site I should not like to express myself too positively until I have a further opportunity after the snow has gone to examine different possible sites and to have tests made for water; but I think it very likely that a better site than the present one can be selected; and accordingly the present building need not be taken into consideration. It would answer for dining-room in case the school were near by; but is is not a valuable building, and if discarded it could be given to a destitute family for a dwelling.

Though the figures above given would indicate that the school population of the two reserves, in case of the closing of the industrial school, would be 40 children, yet for a few years to come it is unlikely that a larger attendance than about 30 could be secured, as several of those included in the 40 now enumerated are 14 or 15 years of age and would not likely attend. A building for 30 or 35 pupils
would answer the requirements; for in case of any material increase in the school population an additional teacher and a separate class-room would be required.

The question of conveying the Stony children will not be affected by the selection of the site. Moreover, I think it likely the Cree children will also have to be conveyed, if the best results are to be obtained, no matter which site is selected.

A few of the Crees asked that boarding accommodation be provided in connection with the teacher's dwelling, as has been done elsewhere; but unless the Department has decided to adopt this plan uniformly I would not recommend it.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Referring to your letter of the 28th ult., relative to the new day school and teacher's dwelling which it is proposed to erect on Red Pheasant's reserve during the coming summer, I have the honour to report further as follows:

It appears to me that there is little room for doubt as to the advisability of amalgamating the Red Pheasant and Stony schools, as the amalgamation should contribute in some measure both to the saving of expenditure and to the efficiency of the work. It is true the Stony children would have to be conveyed to and from school, which would involve an increase of expenditure; but in most other respects there would be a saving effected through the union of the schools; and for the outlay involved in the conveying of the children there would be a return in a better and more uniform attendance. As all who have had this question before their attention since it was first raised are of one mind as to the advantages of the amalgamation of the schools, I shall assume that the suggestion has received, or will receive, the approval of the Department, in order to be able to proceed on this basis to a consideration of the size and site of the proposed buildings.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
While the actual school population of the two bands, in the event of the closing of the Battleford school, as shown in my letter of the 21st ult. will be 40 pupils, yet as it is practically certain that most of those approaching the age limit of 15 years will not attend, it would be safe to figure upon an attendance of 30 as a maximum; it will rarely be larger and generally in all probability considerably smaller. Of course, much depends upon the interest and enthusiasm of the teacher who may be placed in charge, and the support he receives. Under present conditions he will be assured of sympathy and support in his efforts from the agent and the farmer, both of whom are intelligent men and concerned about the progress of the Indians in educational and other respects. In case both these bands continue to occupy these reserves, concerning which they appear quite settled at the present time, the school population is liable to vary, and very likely to increase within the next few years; but there should not be more than 30 pupils to one teacher in any of our Indian schools; and in the event of the actual attendance becoming materially increased the best way to meet the circumstances would be to provide an additional class-room and a second teacher.

The new school on James Smith's reserve affords space and accommodation for a maximum of 24 pupils; but the school-room is not well proportioned, being too narrow in proportion to its length, a condition which along with other disadvantages renders the blackboard space on the right of the pupils less valuable than it otherwise would be. To adapt this building to the circumstances now under consideration, that is, to the requirements of an attendance of 30 pupils, I would suggest that the width of the building be increased from 17 to 21 feet, or better to 21' 6", and that the height of the ceiling be made 12 ft. instead of 11 ft. These changes will afford the necessary air space and floor space according to the Department's regulations, and will make a well proportioned school room.
With regard to the site for the proposed new buildings, I may say that at the time of my last visit to these reserves there was still too much snow on the ground to admit of our leaving the beaten trail for the purpose of making a minute examination of the surface, elevation, drainage, etc., of different possible sites. The site of the present school on Red Pheasant's reserve is clear, well drained, and favourable from a sanitary point of view, and has the advantage of being on the shore of a small lake of good water. But it is not quite central even for Red Pheasant's band; and would be less central for the two bands. All the Stony children would have to be conveyed to and from a school so situated, five miles each way; and to secure a full attendance of the Cree children it is probable some of those to the south-east would also have to be conveyed. The present site is convenient to the Church of England mission, which might have some advantages. It is also convenient to the farm buildings, which, however, are to be rebuilt presently and possibly not on the same site.

The locality referred to in my letter of the 21st ult., as that on which the Indians had set their minds offers many advantages; and now that the season is favourable for the purpose tests should be made for water there, a question which should be settled before a change of location is decided upon. The determination of the exact location of the buildings need occasion no delay in the alteration of the plans or the letting of the contract, so far as I can judge, as there is nothing in this that can affect the calculations of any contractor in figuring out a tender. If good water is to be had I think the location last referred to, which is near the line between the two reserves, affords the greatest advantages; and I could make an opportunity to go over the ground carefully with the Agent and select a suitable site if the Department should approve of this suggestion.
With regard to the teacher's residence, it is my opinion that the building on John Smith's reserve is suited as to both plan and dimensions to the requirements of the proposed amalgamated school hereunder consideration. The attendance of pupils may be expected to be as large, as the school population is considerably larger; and it is probable the teacher and his family will require accommodation similar to that afforded in the dwelling at John Smith's.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

RED PHEASANT DAY SCHOOL.

This school is situated on the Red Pheasant Reserve and serves the Stony Reserve as well. The school is a modern building 22 x 24 ft. with basement. It is heated with a hot air furnace and is a good frame building on a stone foundation. The walls and roof require repainting as the paint has not been renewed since the building was erected seven years ago. The teacher's dwelling and pupils dining room is also a commodious frame building. The interior of the dwelling has been recently kalsomined throughout by the teacher. The outer walls and roof require painting.

The old well is situated about 100 yards from the school at the edge of a slough. It does not provide sufficient water and should be deepened at once and put in order and a pump provided. The water supply is now hauled from the farm house over a mile away.

Mr. E. V. Bird and his wife have just recently been placed in charge as teacher and field matron, respectively. I feel satisfied that the Department has made a good selection in these people both of whom have had considerable experience at teaching Indians. A large garden has been planted and allowed to become a forest of weeds. Mr. Bird, although only two weeks at the school has got it cleaned up and is also getting the premises neat and tidy. Two drivers are employed to bring the children to school. The number enrolled is 25, six girls and nineteen boys. The average attendance during the past year is 20, which is good for an Indian day school. The class standing shows 19 in Standard I and 6 in Standard II. As the school has just been re-opened the attendance was small only six being present on the date of my visit. They looked bright as well as being clean and tidy.

Dear Sir,

The Indians on the Red Pheasant and Stoney Reserves have requested me to institute Evening Classes for them this Fall and Winter.

The request comes principally from the Stoney Indians, whom I think would be greatly benefitted, as only a small minority speak English to any extent.

In accordance with the Regulations I propose holding two sessions per week of at least one and one half hours duration at 7-0 p.m., on Monday and Thursday evenings.

The subjects of instruction, according to the Regulations, shall be English, including Composition and Literature, Penmanship and Business Forms; Arithmetic; Canadian History and Civics. I would, however, suggest that Agriculture be added or substituted in this curriculum.

If these classes are inaugurated there will be a minimum attendance of at least ten persons.

I shall be glad to have your approval together with any instructions or suggestions as to the curriculum, conduct, etc.

I visited this school, which is situated on the Red Pheasant reserve, on October 1st. The pupilage for this school is drawn from the Red Pheasant and Stony reserves. There are two drivers engaged to take the children to and from the school, one from each reserve. There are 21 pupils on the roll, 11 boys and 10 girls. The average attendance for the quarter ending September 30th was 13-2. The teacher, Mr. N.I. Roberts, was appointed last May. He holds a Second Class Professional Teacher's Certificate for the Province of Saskatchewan, and appears to be fairly well qualified for his work. His wife, Mrs. Edith Roberts, acts as Field Matron for the reserve. The pupils in the school are all in the Primary Grades, and it is a difficult matter to obtain satisfactory progress in a school such as this where the attendance is irregular.

Buildings

The school buildings are in a good state of repair, and the school room, children's dining room, and teacher's residence are kept very clean and tidy. The school premises also found in a tidy condition, but noted that some repairs the fence were required. The water supply is not large but is sufficient for their present requirements and the water is of a very good quality. The class room is heated by hot air and is quite large enough to take care of any attendance which may be anticipated from these two reserves.

Sir,

I beg to report that I have Mr & Mrs Roberts resignations, as teacher and Field Matron respectively at Red Pheasant and Stony reserves, to take effect at the end of November. Mr Roberts will not perform his duties any more, but Mrs Roberts will continue the Field Matron work till that date. Mr Roberts has been informed by the Doctors that he will not be able to teach any more for a while but will have to take outdoor occupation, in the mean time Miss Ruth Johnson as substitute teacher will continue teaching and would like to carry it on till the Xmas Holidays, but this would mean hiring a temporary Matron for three weeks and as the house is only equipped with a cook stove and no other household goods, they would hardly move out this material for three weeks work.

The attendance generally, is so poor and as the Indians of both reserves apparently use every excuse to keep their children or avoid sending them to school, that I am inclined to recommend that the school be closed up and the boarding schools used. It is certain that the attendance does not justify the cost of keeping this school open with two school drivers, with matron and teacher and also the upkeep of the place, the only difficulty would be the absence of a Field Matron, and this could be overcome if the Department would appoint a nurse to cover this work as well as the Sweet Grass and Moosomin Reserves, she could be boarded very cheaply at the Farm Instructors places at each of these reserve and be from one to the other as the case demanded.

It is costing well over ten dollars a day to operate this school, with rarely over twelve small children in attendance and it is almost necessary to use coercion to get them there.
Sir,

These two reserves are about half and half Anglican and Roman Catholic and it is very hard to make a success of a denominational school and this school has never been what could be called a success, if shut down for a while and any available children recruited for the boarding schools or rather compelled to go, might bring these Indians to time and if occasion warranted, the school could be reopened again.

The few that are compelled to attend are so irregular, one or two months there and a month away, that at the end of the year, there is very little benefit to the pupil. This cannot be overcome as the parents claim they have to go away to earn a living and take the children with them, if I go after them about it, there reply is always the same, that "if you feed us we will stay" as there is no rations to feed families for this purpose I cannot go any further with it and that is about the situation of the Red Pheasant day school.

I have purchased five tons of hay for the school before knowing of Mr Roberts resignation, but have made no arrangements for fuel and will not do so till I receive further instructions from the Department, there is enough fuel and supplies on hand to finish the present term.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your 105-6-1 of the 28th ultimo, suggesting the advisability of closing the Red Pheasant Indian Day School at the end of the calendar year, and reply to say that I heartily concur in this move. This school has not been getting results, and the cost of management is exceedingly high, almost $12.00 a day I am told, and it seems to me a very unwise policy to keep it open any longer, in view of the fact that we have two Anglican Residential Schools where these children can be admitted, viz:- Onion Lake and Elkhorn.

I am led to believe that we will experience difficulty in getting the parents to consent to send these children away to school, and the Agent says that they will not be sent for a year. This, of course, is absurd; they should be sent to school at the first of the year without fail, and, if necessary, compulsory measures should be taken to do this. The Moosomin Indians are a hard lot to handle, but I think it would be unwise to allow the children to remain at home any length of time if the school is closed. The parents should be warned of this now, and with your authority I will have Dr. Norquay at Battleford examine each child and make a report.

Kindly advise me what action you propose taking, so that I can take the matter up with the Principal of the Onion Lake School, and also the Elkhorn School if necessary,

Your obedient servant,

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Reasons why the School should not be closed now:

1. The Bishop of Saskatchewan has worked very effectively hand in hand with the Indian Department in the work of placing these Day Schools on a good footing. He has tried to work jointly with the Department on a certain policy and I feel therefore that it would be advisable to wait till he comes back before the question of closing the School is raised.

2. In the meantime we can find a teacher who will look upon his work at the school as a Cause. There are children growing up and I feel that by June next there should be others added to the roll. I shall give the school my personal attention as I do with the Little Pine and Thunder child Day Schools.

3. I feel that once the School is closed, there is very small chance of its ever being reopened. This being so, a fair trial should be given to it before it is closed.

I would therefore recommend that the Commission ask the Indian Department to defer the question of closing the School at Red Pheasants till the end of June 1927.

Yours sincerely,

Edward Ahenakew

Dear Canon:

With reference to the proposal to close the Red Pheasant's Day School I have this to report:

Prior to Mr. Roberts' appointment it was difficult to find a teacher for the School; this was owing to the fact that the Indian Agent asked us to recommend a married couple to take the teacher's and matron's positions respectively. There was difficulty to find a suitable combination. The other reason was that Archdeacon Mackey's health was failing when he was looking for the appointments for the school.

Mr. and Mrs. Roberts were appointed eventually. My own impression of Mr. Roberts from the beginning was that he had not that energy which is needed for an Indian School if there is to be success. However, he had a good report from the Provincial Inspector and I could not report incompetent work on the face of that. We usually try to get missionary heartedness in our teachers; he seemed to have had none. The result was that there seemed to be lack of motive power to enable him to put his heart into his work and he failed to get the confidence and the continued support of the parents. Any teacher that shows results with the children will have the support of the Indian parents.

Mr. Roberts' health was not the best and he asked for leave of absence a few months ago. Miss Johnson was appointed temporary teacher with Mrs. Roberts continuing to act as Matron.

I hear that Mr. and Mrs. Roberts have now resigned their resignation to take effect at the end of this month, November. I went to Red Pheasant's a week ago and I find the following facts:

1. There are 16 children on the roll.
2. There are two drivers in connection with the school each getting 2 dollars a day.
3. The children get the mid-day meal.
4. There were about 12 children at school on the day I was there. If this were the average the cost would be near one dollar per child per day.
5. Mrs. Roberts is willing to stay till Christmas with Miss Johnson, in order to tide us over the time that would be needed for arranging for other workers, if the school continues.
6. I heard from one or two sources that Miss Johnson is doing good work and that the attitude of the parents is favorable to her.
PRINCE ALBERT,
SASKATCHEWAN

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. INSPECTOR MAGEE,
dated September 27th, 1927, on his in-
spection of the Red Pheasant Indian
Day School.

Original on File 105-6-6.

Teacher - Henry Reynolds.

Success. - Fair. An energetic and alert teacher
but not fully in sympathy with his pupils who
differ in mode of thought from children of white
parents.

The teacher is confining his attention
to reading, writing, number-work, nature work and
modelling with plasticine. He has not paid much
attention as yet to drawing and I suggested to
him that he might use this as a means of interest-
ing his pupils and leading them thus to a greater
interest in other school work. He is also giving
some attention to the practice of oral composition.
The children are not advanced beyond Grade 1.

What is wanted of a teacher in such a
school, it seems to me, is that he (or she) should
be so in sympathy with the pupils that he would
learn what interests them and make use of such
material to prepare reading, number-work, and com-
position lessons which would especially appeal to
the minds of these pupils for it is not natural
that the same things would interest these pupils
as is of interest to white children.
RED PHEASANT AND STONY DAY SCHOOL

I visited this school on January 20th. Mr. H. Reynolds has been appointed as teacher since my last visit, and his wife as Field Matron for the reserves. Mrs. Reynolds also prepares the mid-day meal for the school children. They both impressed me as being well qualified to fill their respective positions.

There are 24 pupils enrolled: 12 boys and 12 girls. There were 19 present: 10 boys and 9 girls.

The average attendance for the December Quarter was 16.39 but an improvement was noted in the attendance for January. Two drivers are provided and there should be no excuse for not having a full attendance except in cases of sickness.

The parents are indifferent and do not appear to appreciate and take an active interest in the school. The attendance has been better under Mr. Reynolds and I look for further improvement as his influence becomes greater.

As an example of the attitude of the Indians I spoke to one man who resides not more than three
hundred yards from the school and asked him why his children were not attending. His excuse was that the driver had not called for them and if we wanted the children we should see that the driver brought them. I talked to that Indian quite forcibly.

The pupils were clean and warmly clothed although some of them had a ragged appearance.

The school-room was clean but should be re-decorated. The twelve double desks are old and broken and will have to be replaced very soon.

Wash basins and individual towels are provided and the children required to clean up each morning.

Water is obtained from a well. The supply is ample and of good quality. The school premises were tidy but the fence requires repairing.

Mrs. Reynolds visits the houses on the reserves and appears to be very interested in her work.

RED PHEASANT DAY SCHOOL.

This School is on the Red Pheasant reserve and close to the boundary of the Stony reserve and is to supply the needs of both reserves.

It is under the Anglican church but supposed to Non-denominational and for the use of the Catholics as well, but is not very successfull in so far as the Catholics attending, some do attend, but there is always a sort of underground opposition from the parents and Missionaries.

The present teacher is Mr Henry Reynolds assisted by Mrs Reynolds as Field Matron and they are doing very good work, both attendance and progress being better than they have been for a long time. They take a genuine interest in the work and are good substantial people and already have the full confidence of the Indians of both reserves.

Two school drivers are employed here, one for each reserve and both have circuits of approximately seven miles to make twice a day, they also act as truant officers and usually take quite an interest in seeing the children get to school when they should.

This as well as Little Pine are improved Day schools where a hot noon meal is served for the Children and in many cases means the health of children. The Field Matrons prepare this mean, which usually consists of Hot stew with Beans, peas, Barley or rice and the usual school biscuit, some days Oatmeal porridge is given as a change and the children all relish this meal.

The buildings with the exception of some interior decorating that is required and in good shape, and this will be done as soon as the school is closed for the holidays.

Dear Sir,

Now that the Dominion Government has become fairer and more generous (see Pension), I beg that you will accede to my request, which I have delayed until my husband of the Battleford Court House Staff should be retired, this retirement comes into effect the end of this month after 12 years service; he is 72 years of age, his monthly salary is now $110.00, the pension will probably be half that amount, an impossible sum for two people of our age to live on.

I am asking for a Pension for myself on account of 24 years continuous service as a Department Teacher on Indian Reserves (with never a reprimand) at a Salary of $25.00 per month—without any other grant from Church or outside sources. Not only did I teach, but cut out the clothes for my pupils & helped the mothers to make them; provided a daily lunch at our own house and expense, to encourage children to attend, also acted as housekeeper for all these years—without any of the modern buildings and comforts now provided for department officials.

It is worth a good Pension from the time I resigned, for an educated white woman to have lived among Indians for 24 years. It would not create a precedent; for to my knowledge, there is no other Day School Teacher in Saskatchewan, with such length of service, I am now 66 years of age.

I commenced teaching 21 September 1888, in the Day School on John Smith's Reserve, Duck Lake Agency, living there with my brother who was farming Instructor and unmarried; after several years we were exchanged with W. M. Joseph Price, Red Pheasants Reserve, Battleford Agency. My brother left Battleford for the South African Campaign—Sometime afterwards I married Robert Jefferson, farming Instructor of that Reserve & also of the Stony Reserve, I still taught until 1912.

The Indians on the Red Pheasant Reserve are very disturbed over the rumors which have reached them regarding the Department's reported reluctance to continue the school at Red Pheasant. Considering the weather for the months involved since the New Year, the attendance has been very good. There was also an outbreak of flu during January and February. The Archdeacon who knows the situation very well writes: "I do not think the Stony Indians could be expected to send their children to school from their new farms across the railway, some of which are seven miles from the school. It is considerably cheaper for the Department to provide transportation for these children than to give them a school of their own." You will notice that some of the Indians in their anxiety to retain the school privileges had thought of moving in nearer the school but this would hamper very much the Department's encouragement of farming among the Indians, because they must scatter where there is suitable land." The Archdeacon is of the opinion that it would be advisable to continue both drivers for the school and that the Stony driver at least should not be discontinued.

I am sending you herewith a petition which has come in from the Indian Bands.

I hope the Department will be able to retain this school which the Indians value so much.

Yours sincerely,

W.T. Saskatoon

Red Pheasant School

This school is a good demonstration of what can be done by a man and woman who consider their duties extend beyond teaching the children to read and write.

To Dr. McGill

Report on Red Pheasant Indian Day School

I visited the above mentioned school on October 9th. At the time of my inspection the teacher was absent but I met him on his way to town, where he was attending a teacher's convention.

The school is a frame building and quite old. I was informed by the Agent that he had word from the Branch last year that a new school was to be erected here, only on a different site. The building, although old, appeared to be in a fair state of repair. I also visited the home of Mr. Morgan, the teacher, and had a conversation with Mrs. Morgan. She informed me that the house was still quite comfortable.

This institution serves both the Stoney and Red Pheasant Reserves and I am afraid the Indian children do not attend very regularly, as some of them live quite a distance from the school and it is too cold for them to walk long distances in Winter. However, as I pointed out in my general report, some of the Stoney Indians move to a village during the Winter time, where the houses are very unsanitary. There is a mid-day meal given at the school and it is cooked by Mrs. Morgan in her home.

I expect to receive a Provincial Inspector's report on this school shortly and I will then take up the matter of the attendance with the Indian Agent, as from my observation there might have been more children attending this Institution than there were.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Agencies.

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit my report for the month of March, 1941, as follows:

Attendance at the Red Pheasant Day School has fallen away badly this winter. This is partly due to the fact that transportation of the children, at the expense of the Department, was reduced this term, partly due to the fact that the Indians are very poor and unable to purchase suitable clothing for the long walk for the children in the cold. In addition, there is a resentment of the Indians towards the teacher, whose heart is very much in the war, ever since it started, but not very much in the school. This man, (Mr. C.E. Morgan) had a good school until the war started, but ever since the beginning of last term, he has been trying to get into the army. I have a feeling now that, the sooner he gets into the army, the better it will be for the school. I believe, also, that for next winter, the transportation facilities will have to be restored to this school.

In considering the question of the mid-day meal at the Indian Day Schools the matter of the growing of garden vegetables has great importance.

With this in view, the fact that the day schools are closed for the months of July, August and September is regrettable as these are the gardening months.

I have wondered if there is any reason why the open and closed dates for day schools could not be altered, suggesting closing for the month of July and opening for August and September. Then, with a view to saving fuel and transportation difficulties, closing again for the months of January and February.

I have not discussed it with the Indians of the Little Pine and Thunderchild Reserves, where we also have day schools, but would do so if the Department favours the change, and I believe that the Indians of these bands, also, would agree.

Attention of Mr. Phelan.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 105-6-1 of the 7th instant. Upon receipt of it I immediately took the matter up with Mr. Ostrander and I am now in receipt of a communication from him.

Probably one reason for the number of children present on the list of the Red Pheasant Indian Day School is that some of the children who were attending Onion Lake School have been going there since it burnt down and have not as yet gone to Prince Albert to attend the school there but Mr. Ostrander has the following to say:

"I would feel inclined to re-open this school for the next term if we had the right kind of a teacher, and the decision in this regard should rest with the Church authorities and the responsibility be theirs to get the right kind or we should not re-open the school. If there was a man and wife at this school, and transportation provided, it would be worth while continuing."

I more or less agree with the Agent that a man and his wife are necessary at this point.

Evidently the building was condemned by the late Dr. Robertson in 1938. In all due respect to the late Dr. Robertson I wonder whether he was a qualified person to state whether a building was habitable or not. However, apparently the school building is very cold when the weather outside is down to forty degrees below zero.

In winding up his letter to me Mr. Ostrander has the following to say:

"My recommendation in this..........."
"My recommendation in this connection would be that if the Church Authorities have the right kind of a teacher in sight, preferably a man with a wife to live with him and assist him, I would be in favour of the appointment being made now, and they could be getting their feet while waiting the building of a new school after the war. If their selection is a young girl with the choice of living alone at the school or boarding with the Farming Instructor and his wife, or the cast-off from some other Indian school, I am definitely against re-opening at this time and it seems that, at the present time, their only choice is either one of this description."

In conclusion I would say that I think it would be a mistake to close down this school at the present time. Let us do the best we can while the war is on and the Church should be able to get a couple that might be fit to carry this institution on for a year or so. I have been at the school in question and know what it is like, and I am going to be there again this Summer. My recommendation would be to ask the Church to endeavour to take over this school for the present time. I am sure if the school is cold we could do something to fix it up a little warmer probably than it is and I shall go into this matter when I visit Battleford Agency during the Summer.

Dear Canon Hives:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 2nd instant, in which you intimate that Mr. Ross has decided against accepting the position of teacher at the Red Pheasant Indian Day School. It is unnecessary to state that this information was very disturbing to the officials of this Branch and to myself.

I may state, by way of explanation, that both the late Dr. Robertson and the General Superintendent of Indian Agencies, Mr. Christianson, have on more than one occasion recommended the construction of a new school on the Red Pheasant Reserve. However, in view of war conditions, the scarcity of labour, the scarcity of materials and the limited funds at our disposal, it was not possible to build this school. As a matter of actual fact, we have not been able to rebuild a dozen or more schools throughout the Dominion that have been destroyed by fire within the last two or three years, and we naturally feel that these schools should have a prior claim upon the Department. Just how soon funds will be placed at our disposal for the repair and construction of school buildings, I am not of course in a position to state. I do know, however, that it is the intention of the Government to proceed with a comprehensive building program in the immediate post-war period. In the meantime, I am communicating with the Indian Agent at Battleford, expressing the hope that he may be able to undertake the repairs necessary to justify the re-opening and operation of the Red Pheasant School.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letters of August 7th and 13th with respect to the appointment of Mr. P. G. Kehler to the vacancy of teacher on the Red Pheasant Indian Reserve.

Mr. Bell notifies me that he has had no definite word as to the appointment of Mr. Kehler.

May I ask that Mr. Kehler be notified of the acceptance of his appointment so that he may make his plans to occupy the position.

It seems a little unreasonable to ask Mr. Kehler to make a journey from Kleefeld in Manitoba merely to look over the situation before beginning his work. Mr. Kehler has been told of the type of work and the difficulties that are peculiar to work among the Indians.

The previous applicant for the position of teacher refused to remain at the school having seen the buildings in a most deplorably dirty condition. The house and school have recently been swept and cleaned so that the need for inspection for this reason has been eliminated. There are 12 or 13 children from Red Pheasant Reserve awaiting the reopening of school. It is hoped that children from the Stony Reserve will increase this attendance.

I trust that the school will be reopened forthwith and that the appointment of Mr. Kehler be made. I am writing to Mr. Kehler again advising him that the nomination is apparently acceptable to the department but leaving it to him to decide what action he

Dear Sir:

With reference to the vacancies at Day Schools on Red Pheasant I.R., and Little Pine I.R., may I assure you that every effort is being made to secure teachers for these schools so that they may open at the beginning of the new term in September.

I have been in communication with several teachers and I believe that the difficulty arises from the salary offered although none have actually stated this. I have noticed that no further communication comes whenever the amount of the salary has been mentioned.

The minimum salary offered in provincial schools is $1200.00 per annum. The teacherage, with fuel, cost of living bonus together with the isolation on these reserves seems to lack somewhat in attracting teachers to these positions.

However I am continuing the search for suitable teachers and am hopeful that nominations will be sent forward in due course.

With regard to the Little Pine School because of the promise of an experienced teacher who is not free at present to take over the school but who will definitely do so next year, the Rev. A. Spence has signified his willingness to continue his teaching for the present year. Therefore I send his nomination forward to the Department for reappointment as teacher.

Dear Sir:

In the matter of replacement of the teacher at Red Pheasant Day School now vacant by the resignation of Mrs. A. Lindberg, I have been unsuccessful in securing a successor to Mrs. Lindberg.

Three very favorable applicants were interviewed but for reasons beyond the scope of the department's influence made the appointment impossible.

I have therefore made further contact with Mrs. Lindberg, who has been living near the reserve and operating with her husband a small country store, to see if she would consider returning to the school for a period of one year that is until next June 30th. This course was taken after representations were made by several of the Indian parents of children attending school who were pleased with the progress of their children under Mrs. Lindberg, and an apparent desire to have the school re-opened for the current term. Furthermore Canon Sheasby has spoken in high praise of the general influence for good that Mrs. Lindberg has been among the people of the Reserve. Bishop Hallam is most desirous that the school shall be opened without any break if at all possible. It is with these circumstances before me that I make the nomination of Mrs. Lindberg for the position of teacher at Red Pheasant.

Mrs. Lindberg's application is already on file in your office so that it is not renewed at this time. Not having the salary schedule with me at the time, I assured Mrs. Lindberg that her salary would be the same as last year $125.00 per teaching month. I believe that the salary scale would grant her a higher rate of salary than that for a second class certificate and 10 years experience. Mrs. Lindberg if appointed will live in residence.
at the teacherage and will serve for the full term until June 30th 1948.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have had an enquiry, regarding the Red Pheasant Reserve, North Battleford, Saskatchewan.

The Indians would like to know whether, or not, there is any lease, covering the property on which the Anglican Mission is situated. They would further like to know whether better provision could be made for the establishment of schools on the reserve, so that the children can properly attend. There are some forty-seven children on this reserve, between the ages of five and sixteen, but only about ten attending school, because of the long distance, which they have to travel. Apparently there are a number of children on the Stoney Reserve also. The Family Allowance cheques are payable to the parents for the children, only if they attend school, and the school facilities are so far from the homes that in winter time it is almost impossible for the children to attend with any regularity.

I would like to know what can be done to remedy the situation, as apparently some of these children have over six miles to travel with no roads and no proper facilities and, in many cases, the families are too poor to provide even horses for transportation.

Apparently some resolution, with regard to the building of a school, and the moving of the present one to a more convenient location, has been sent to the Agent.

Yours very sincerely,

G. H. Castleman,
M. P. for Yorkton.

The question of the Anglican Mission owning land on the Red Pheasant Reserve was taken up with the Church authorities and they informed me that they did not own any land on the Red Pheasant Reserve.

We are at the present time conducting a survey to locate an adequate water supply for the new school to be constructed on Red Pheasant Reserve.

There are about forty four children of school age on the Red Pheasant reserve but a considerable number of them are quite capable of walking to school. Last winter was an exceptional one as far as depth of snow was concerned, but it was only during February and March that the snow became so deep. Previous to that the weather was very mild and not a great deal of snow. I do not consider it a hardship for children over nine years of age to walk to school. The Family Allowance is not cut off for irregular attendance if the child or children live a distance from school. The children on the Mosquito reserve were provided with transportation to school so that there was no reason why they were not regular attenders. Possibly the Red Pheasant people figure that transportation should have been provided for their children as well.

The question of the families being too poor to provide horses for their children to ride to school or drive is I think stretching the truth a little. Practically every family on Red Pheasant Reserve sold around a thousand dollars worth of hay last year. I know of one that came to the North Battleford Fair with six hundred dollars in his pocket and of course went home broke. Most of their troubles are caused by their own refusal to be guided by the advice of their Farming Instructor. They desire to
They desire to go their own way as long as they have a few dollars in their pockets and when they get a little hard up shout that the Department will not assist them. This condition is enhanced by a couple of "sea lawyers" in the Band. They make their living by bumming from house to house and doing a lot of talking.

To put a school on the reserve that would be three miles from the furthest away home would be an impossibility. A certain number will be further away than that in any case, but I do feel that they should make a definite effort to help themselves to a certain extent in seeing that their children do get an education.

With the Family Allowance cheque coming in every month and if they have any ambition to earn a few dollars I do not see why they cannot purchase a pony to take the children to school. They should not be short of feed as there is plenty of hay on that reserve every year. All they need to do is cut it and stack it. A horse is not a very expensive item in this part of the province at the present time and his feed would cost little or nothing except the labour of putting it up.

Red Pheasant Indian Day School

Building:
Freshly painted building looks well. It should last for years.

Heating:
The new stove has not yet arrived.

Water:
Efforts to locate a well have failed. We will have to continue hauling water.

Enrollment:
Of 32 enrolled, 25 were present. 11 of the 15 children were present.

Furniture:
A purchase order for desks sufficient to cope with the enrollment, has been received.

Play Equipment:
This is in short supply.

School Supplies:
There are shortages. For example, in grade 4 7 readers are needed; the school has only 3 old ones.

Management:
The teacher is admittedly an older woman with little modern training or experience, and the Provincial Inspector was not pleased, I am told, at conditions during his visit. But Mr. Assistant Birch reports considerable improvement, and certainly I could not see any evidence of bad behaviour. The children are getting accustomed to the teacher. Mr. Birch was requested to continue his frequent unheralded visits. This is not likely to entail neglect of his other functions.

Teacher:
The teacher reports that she has not yet received any installment of her salary. She admitted not having forwarded tax form T. I. Her husband is in a home for incurables in the U. S. A.

Teacherage:
A new set of steps from the kitchen down into the basement is an imperative necessity and no delay should be allowed in replacing the present dangerous installation.

Dear Sir:

Mr. N. J. Kroeker has commenced his duties as teacher on the Red Pheasant Reserve. Due to weather conditions in the west he was unable to make train connections but we were able to take him to the Reserve by team on Thursday. He is staying for the present with Mr. Burrah, but will move into the house as soon as the renovation work which Mr. Bell contemplates is completed.

Mr. Kroeker appears to be an earnest, sincere man of quiet disposition. In his approach to his work, which is new to him as far as Indian Work is concerned, he was very thoughtful and enquiring. Knowing something of the difficulties before him and of the run-down appearance of the school property he is prepared to take on the work with the sense of obtaining a satisfying vocation and career. I was attracted to him and if his work is as satisfactory as we have been led to expect I am sure that we have a good man. His wife and two children will join him, probably after the present school term.

The school has been very satisfactorily repaired for use. The house has some minor repair work to be done and the interior is to be redecorated. For all of this I am grateful for it will be an encouragement to these people to create a home. I should like to urge that some considerable work be done on the grounds about the school and teachorage. The garden has been very much neglected and requires good working in order that proper use can be made of the grounds. Mr. Kroeker is able to teach gardening and I believe his gnomonite background will serve him here in good stead. The fence has all but disappeared. This should be restored since a well kept fence about an isolated property does much to create the atmosphere of respectability and prosperity. The barn at the teachorage also needs some repair work done and since Mr. Kroeker will need a cow I would recommend that this repair be done.
I should like to express by appreciation of the assistance given and of the forbearance of the Department in the treatment of the teachers we have had on the reserve during the past few years. It has been difficult to secure teachers during the time of teacher shortage and those whom we did secure have not always shown the real interest in the problem we have continually to face. It is to be sincerely hoped that the present incumbent will prove as satisfactory as my remarks above would lead one to expect.

Thanking you, and with kindest regards,

Yours faithfully,
