Memorandum:

SUPERINTENDENT OF EDUCATION.

Red Pheasant - New School.

Mr. Ostrander has recommended a new school for the Red Pheasant Reserve. As the present buildings are adequate for the present potential school population of all denominations, it would seem that a greater need for a school exists on the Contiguous Reserve for the Mosquito or Stony band. Fifteen of these children are enrolled at the Red Pheasant school and their transportation costs this Department $3. a day.

There was formerly a school on the Mosquito Reserve under Protestant direction.

Water seems to be hard to find anywhere on the Red Pheasant Reserve. Wells have been sought at various points unsuccessfully, and water has to be hauled to the present Red Pheasant School and teacherage daily.

On the Mosquito Reserve, however, water is stated to be more easily available.

The Roman Catholic children of both these reserves were formerly sent to the Thunderchild Residential School. Some may now be in Muscowequan and Onion Lake.

In 1953 there is the prospect of seventy children of school age on the Red Pheasant Reserve and thirty-eight on the Mosquito Reserve. Of the fifty children presently of school age on the Red Pheasant Reserve thirty are enrolled at the Red Pheasant School which, according to the statistical analysis which appears one folio down accounts for only half the Protestant children from that Reserve whose parents may be keeping their children at home.
claiming that transportation should be provided.

The buildings at Red Pheasant resemble those at Little Pine where we use the lunchroom as a second classroom. If the Roman Catholic population on the Red Pheasant Reserve press for a day school then we might split up the lunchroom and attempt to conduct an additional denominational school on the Assiniboine pattern.

The Mosquito Reserve, however, remains a one-room prospect for many years to come unless the transportation of all pupils of all denominations to the Red Pheasant School is arranged.

Considering the implications for the future, I would suggest that Mr. Superintendent Bell be requested to complete copies of the attached pro forma for the Red Pheasant and Mosquito bands. It would be well to have similar statistics for the Poundmaker, Moosomin, Little Pine and Sweetgrass Reserve.

C.A.F. Clark,
Educational Survey Officer.

Dear Mr. Neary,

I thought you might be interested in following up a method which I used in

ESTABLISHING A WASH ROUTINE
at the Red Pheasant Ind. Day School

We had received about 20 yards of towelling from the Dept. for the 27 pupils and proceeded as follows:

I Preparation:
1. The towels were cut in equal lengths.
2. The pupils each brought a needle and thread to school and hemmed the ends by hand.
3. I now prepared patterns with bold numbers which were traced on white canvass and were cut out in school.
4. The pupils took the towels home and sewed the numbers on and embroidered the edges of the latter.
5. Then a loop was sewed to the edge of each towel.

II Method of Towel Check up
1. I made a list with numbers opposite their names.
2. The towels hang in that order in the hall.
3. Every 1st and 3rd Friday in a month the towels are taken home for laundering and are to be returned on the following Monday.

III Wash Routine
1. I have filled a large kettle with warm water at recess and placed it in the hall.
2. At the appointed time at noon the oldest pupil acts as supervisor helping the younger pupils to get their towels, looking after order, carrying out the slop pail etc.
3. Two other pupils take turns once a week to change the water for the pupils.
4. They wash in definite groups keeping their order, the smallest first.
5. Two large cakes of soap are about a standard requirement for the whole school.

The giggling and chattering tells me they areas happy as ducks enjoying life and establishing proper habits.

Sincerely,

With regard to the vacancy of the position of the teacher for Red Pheasant School, I have been endeavoring ever since I was acquainted with the fact of the vacancy, to secure a teacher for the school. I have today received a letter from Mr. Silversides of Regina indicating that he is not at present interested in the school at Red Pheasant.

At your suggestion I will place another advertisement in the papers. There are several schools in this immediate vicinity without teachers and I am given to understand from the school superintendent that the teacher shortage is a matter of concern throughout the Province.

At the present moment I am commissioned only to act in this matter in accordance with the established procedure by which the Church authority nominates the teacher to the Department. If as your letter suggests that this method should be abrogated it should be done by the Department in communication with the Bishop. Personally, I should be sorry to see the discontinuance of this practice since I have been looking forward to the possibility of a closer co-operation between Department and Church.

I regret that the Department has discontinued the practice of sending the School Bulletins and Salary Revision Schedules as these were always a help to me in discussing teaching matters with prospective teachers &c. However I have found the regional Indian Office most co-operative and understanding in our common difficulties.

I shall inform you immediately when a satisfactory application has been received. There have been only two rejected applicants, one on account of illiteracy and the other for unsatisfactory training and also adverse comment from the Agency in which previous teaching had been carried on.

Thanking you for your interest,

yours faithfully,

H.E. [Signature]

With reference to Department Army Message of the 23rd instant regarding the appointment of Mr. Nelson A. Blackwell as Indian day school teacher at the Red Pheasant Reserve, of the Battleford Agency, I regret to advise that Mr. Blackwell declined to accept the appointment when informed that his salary would be $228.00 per teaching month.

I have asked Indian Superintendent C.S. Bell to contact Reverend Canon Hives, asking him to submit a recommendation covering one of the other teachers who has applied for the position. I may say there have been many applications, and I have no doubt that we will be able to secure the services of a suitable teacher from one of these.

With reference to the advertisement which was placed in several papers asking for applications for this appointment it is my opinion that the advertisement was well thought out and I see nothing wrong with it, but apparently a number of the teachers who have applied assume from the wording of the advertisement that if they have sufficient years of experience in any school, and high qualifications, they should expect to start at the maximum salary of $3120.00. I may say that in telephone conversation with Reverend Canon Hives he seemed to be labouring under the same misapprehension. I believe it would expedite matters considerably if I was informed of the exact process by which the starting salary of a teacher applicant is decided. I regret to say that I am not at all clear on this myself, and I am, therefore, not in a very good position to advise others. I was confused, for instance, over the application of Miss Virginia Bettschen who applied for a position at the File Hills School and who has about fifteen years teaching experience, with a B.A. and B.Ed. By what process of calculation was it decided that the very maximum which could be paid to Miss Bettschen for a starting salary was $2,640.00 per annum? Compared to this Mrs. Sprague, the teacher at the Little Pine Indian Day School, of the Battleford Agency, is being paid $3,000.00 a year,
with one degree, a B.A.

I am not criticising Department officials in any way in asking for this information, but I would like to be in a better position to tell an applicant, with some degree of accuracy, what salary he or she could hope to receive if appointed. By not being able to give this information immediately we might sometimes miss the opportunity of getting a very excellent teacher into our service.

J.P.B. Ostrander,

You are far from being the first of our officials
to be somewhat confused by the terms of the salary schedule.
The main difficulty seems to be with regard to the general
regulation allowing a maximum only of five years' service for
provincial teaching service. After all, we must be fair to
these teachers who remained on in Indian schools; many of them
doing a good job, during the days when our salaries were very
low. It is standard practice to grant so many years of credit
for outside experience and we have set a rather generous maximum
at five years.

I can best illustrate this situation by the following
examples:

(a) Miss B. Bettschen

Credit for provincial experience ........ 5 years
Credit for Armed Forces experience ....... 2 "
Total ...... 7 "

This means that Miss Bettschen placed on the 8th year as
a Grade 3 teacher or at a salary of $2,520.00 a year
plus university degree credit of $120.00
or a total of $2,640.00
(b) Mrs. Surage -

Years of provincial experience ........... 2 years

Indian school experience (13 years but did not attend sufficient summer schools and credit only for 9 years ............. 9 "

Total ........................................ 11 "

This would place her at the eleventh year on the scale at $2,880.00 a year but she also has a Bachelor of Arts Degree which entitles her to a bonus of $120.00 per annum. Her salary therefore is ......................... $2,880.00 plus ......................... 120.00 = $3,000.00

The main point of misunderstanding normally arises with regard to credit for provincial experience and I know you will appreciate why we give more credit for Indian school experience than for provincial experience.

The average teacher coming in to our service would get $228.00 a month as a commencing salary with credit for five years of experience and a First Class Certificate. This would entitle them to start at the sixth year as a Grade Three teacher. This five years of credit for provincial experience would be given to a teacher with 12 years of experience or one with 17 years of experience, etc. If a teacher has only 2 years of provincial experience, then she is given credit only for these two years.

I hope this clarifies the situation for you.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Sir;

Re outhouses at Red Pheasant School Buildings,

During an interview I had with the Health Officer, he claimed that if boxes were placed in these buildings to receive refuse, they would only be a harbor for insects in the summer and would freeze up in the winter, making it very inconvenient to clean them out.

I would suggest that in place of boxes, a hole be dug in the ground, to a depth of five or six feet, and the building placed over this.

At this depth the refuse would practically eat itself up, and a little lime and bluestone sprinkled over occasionally, would make a healthy and sanitary closet.

Reference your letter 117054-5-5, December 27th, 1916.

I beg to advise you that I have looked into the matter of the heating of the Red Pheasant and Stoney and Littlepine Schools.

The Red Pheasant and Stoney School has four hot air registers in the school room and one in the lobby. There are two cold air registers, one in the school room and one in the lobby. I have marked these on the plan. There is a foul air register which is marked on the plan but which does not work. Instead of carrying off the foul air, the draught comes down the flue and cold air is projected into the room.

The height of the furnace top to basement ceiling is two feet four inches. The location of the furnace is marked on the plan. The distance from the earth to the joists is three feet. This building is on a stone foundation and a portion can easily be removed if excavating is required.

A stove was put up in the school room this winter and on my last visit, which was a very cold day being 30 degrees below zero with a strong wind, the room was quite comfortable. They informed me that since the stove has been in use they are able to warm the room in the morning in one hour.
In the Littlepine School there are two hot air registers which are situated in the partition between the school room and lobby. These are seven and a half feet from the floor, behind and on either side of the teacher's desk. There are two cold air registers in the school room. In the lobby there is one hot air register behind the door leading into the school room. There is also one cold air register in the lobby. The hot air register in the lobby is in the wall next to the floor. The location of the furnace as marked on the plan is correct.

The distance from the furnace top to the ceiling of the basement is two feet two inches. The height from the earth to the joists in the unexcavated portion of the basement is two feet six inches.

This building has a cement foundation and will be more expensive to remove if excavating is done.

The stove in the school room has been put up since my last visit and regards this Mr. English wrote me on the 9th inst as follows, "I wish to inform you that the stove in the school room is now in use and is a splendid success. I light the fire about 8:45 and in a few minutes the room is quite warm. I now very seldom use the furnace in the basement. The consumption of fuel is now cut down by at least 50%, so that the stove is a success in a double sense."

I have no suggestions to offer excepting that I agree with Inspector Crombie that the furnaces should be placed more central.

Yours obediently,

Indian Agent

S. L. MACDONALD, INDIAN AGENT, BATTLEFORD, SASK.
FORWARDED UNDER COVER OF HIS 9-138 of April 3/34.

Orig. on 1934A-1E.

Red Pheasant Day School

This is an Anglican School, on the Red Pheasant reserve, near the boundary of the Stony reserve and acts for both. Mr Henry Reynolds is in charge.

The buildings of this school are a duplicate of the Little Pine school, but the attendance and progress is not in the same class. The teacher makes a fair effort but is not the type for Indian teaching and would never make a success of an Indian School. The Indians on these reserves are also backward and it would be a hard proposition for any teacher. One of the chief drawbacks is denominational, about 50 percent of these reserves are Catholic and there is a natural opposition to an Anglican school.

One driver is now employed from the Stony reserve which is too far from the school through bush country for children to walk.

The noon meal has been discontinued and the pupils now bring their lunches.

Sir:-

I visited the above named school on January 9th. There were 12 girls and 8 boys present, out of an enrollment of 26 (13 boys and 13 girls). I was quite pleased with conditions as I found them in the classroom at this school. The children appeared bright and spoke up better than I have ever heard them on previous visits. They presented a clean and well nourished appearance. They were warmly clad, although their clothing in some instances was considerably patched.

The children are given a mid-day lunch, consisting of a bowl of vegetable soup with meat in it. At times this is varied by giving them oatmeal porridge. It is interesting to note that the pupils raised money by giving a concert, the proceeds of which were applied towards providing the ingredients for the mid-day meal. The Indian Agent gave them a quarter of beef which was of material assistance.

I am taking this opportunity of again voicing my opinion regarding the importance of providing the children at our day schools with a bowl of nourishing soup at mid-day. Many of the children who come from poor homes, arrive at the school after having very little, if any, breakfast. The mid-day meal they receive there is in many cases the only real nourishing meal they get during the day. It has been reported to me by the teachers that during the forenoon many of the children are in a phlegmatic condition, but -

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
condition, but after they have had their mid-day meal they are bright and take an interest in their lessons as well as in their play. The ingredients for the mid-day meal are inexpensive and I feel that the expense entailed in providing same is justified in view of the effect it has on the condition and health of the children. It is also an incentive to encourage attendance.

The school building is a frame structure with a cement basement. A furnace is provided in the basement, which has not been in use as the pipes are out of order, and a large heating stove is provided which adequately heats the building. The day was not warm when I visited the school, but I found the room quite comfortable. We had a meeting of the Band in the school room which lasted for several hours in the evening and the room was comfortably warm.

As the Stony Reserve is situated at some distance from the school, a driver is provided to bring the children. Until recently a driver was also provided for the Red Pheasant Reserve. This has been discontinued.

The teacher, Mr. Reynolds, appears to be giving very satisfactory service at this school.

Your obedient servant,

W. Murison,
Inspector,
Saskatchewan Inspectorate.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Department letter No.105-6-5, Sept 6th, re Noon Meal at the Day schools at Red Heasant, Little Pine and Roundmakers.

The Biscuits have been received, but the Teachers and Church Authorities think that where the children come a long way, the biscuits do not cover requirements and if it is to be confined to a Hot drink or Soup, the soup would be the most nourishing. During the period mentioned by the Department, Beef is on hand for winter Nations, at 6 and 7 Cents, and would be about $3.50 per Month. Other ingredients, Rice, Pot Barley and Rolled Oats or Beans, would be about $7.00 making a total of $10.50 per Month or $31.50 per quarter as it would be supplied, this is based on Little Pine school, where the attendance is large and would not likely exceed $25.00 per quarter at Red Heasant and Thunderchild.

The Supplies would have to be Purchased at Battleford for Red Heasant, from Wilson & Magee, Little Pine Layton and from Craig Bros Ltd., Turtleford for the Thunderchild School.

Dear Sir,

I beg to advise the Department that the well at the Red Pheasant Reserve has gone dry, and practically all lakes and sloughs on the Reserve have dried up. It is almost impossible to get a water supply, but in order to carry on the school it will be necessary to put in a new well.

Sinking of wells is more or less of a doubtful proposition, and no definite price can be set in advance. However, I anticipate that a new well could be put in for approximately $75.00, and would ask you that authority be allowed for this amount, and if no water is then obtained it will be necessary to further communicate with the Department.

Sept. 3, 1938.

S.L. Macdonald,
Indian Agent,
Battleford.

re Red Pheasant School Driver.

Dear Mr. Macdonald,

I wish to call your attention to the following facts and to the request attached.

The number of children attending the above School from the Red Pheasant Band has increased during the last year. Most of these increases are young pupils and many of them live at a distance from the School. The trails that they have to travel are through rather bushy country and are not safe for young children in winter. Would it be possible to get a driver for these children? I understand that there used to be a driver, but the number of pupils decreased and this was discontinued. A route of about six and one half miles would serve 13 children.

A. Peyachew. 1 age 7
L. Wuttunee. 1 age 7
W. Peyachew. 1 age 7
Mrs. G. Peyachew. 1 age 12
J. Nicotine. 2 ages 12 and 8.
Phillip Armstrong. 2 ages 12 and 10.
M. Morin. 2 ages 13 and 10.
J. Wuttunee. 1 age 10.
J. Bear. 2 ages 10 and 7
Joe Bugler. 1 age 12.
Mrs. J. Douguette. 1 age 9.
S. Benson. 1 age 8.

I hope something satisfactory can be arranged with respect to this matter.

Yours sincerely,

E.A. Morgan
Teacher.
Dear Sir:

I am attaching a letter from Mr. Morgan, Teacher, Red Pheasant Indian Day School, addressed to Agent Macdonald, asking that a driver be allowed from December 1st to April 1st for the school children.

In Mr. Macdonald's letter he states that as Mr. Morgan's letter gives all the details, he does not need to repeat them, except that a driver would make it possible for about four more children than he mentions to attend the school.

He states that this matter was brought up at the Band Meeting which I recently attended, and that he agrees with the Indians that a three-mile trip through the bush trails is not safe for the children, as most of them are seven and eight years of age and Winter travel is often tough for adults.

Mr. Macdonald recommends that a driver be employed for the period mentioned, at the rate of $2.00 per day for school days driven.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

The Secretary,
Dept' of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant enclosing letter received from the teacher of the Red Pheasant School requesting authority to employ a driver to bring the children to the school from December 1 to April 1.

For some time past we have been paying at the rate of $2.00 a day for transporting children to the Red Pheasant Indian Day School. The last account submitted for this service was voucher 325 dated October 6 covering the payment for the month of September, 1938.

In view of the payment already being made it is difficult to understand to what children Mr. Morgan refers in his letter. Possibly he means a different part of the Reserve from that covered by the present driver. Please let me have further particulars in this connection but it is extremely doubtful if our funds will permit allowing more for driving children than is at present provided.

Yours truly,

Dr. Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Regina, Sask.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,
REGINA, SASK., November 18, 1936.

Dear Sir:

Ref.: Your #105-6-5 of November 10th,
Driver, Red Pheasant School.

I find that the driver at present employed at this school
is engaged in driving children from the Stony Reserve to the school,
as there are no children on the Stony Reserve within two miles of the
school.

There is no driver for children living on the Red Pheasant
Reserve. There was one up to about three years ago, but owing to the
poor attendance, it was discontinued on the recommendation of Agent
Macdonald. Attendance now has greatly increased, and the number of
children attending the school, together with the distance they have to
travel, warrants the employment of a driver. A distance of two
three miles, in cold stormy weather, across a Reserve, is too much for
any child. In view of the splendid work being done at this school,
I think a special effort should be made to assist the children to get
there.

We are facing on this Reserve the same as we face on all
others—Indians scattered from one end of the Reserve to the other.
Apparently no effort has been made to centralize the settlement. Our
medical officers have to travel all over the Reserve to see two or three
patients. Our Farming Instructors travel 50 miles where they would be
able to see all the farmers by driving a distance of 5 or 10 miles if
the farmers were centralized. It has cost the Department thousands of
dollars through breaks in machinery due to having to haul a binder or
mower five or ten miles to cut a few acres of grain or hay for an in-
dividual Indian. We have to employ drivers to haul the children to school
for no reason whatever except that the Indian decides to go and build and
settle four or five or six miles from the school.

I have been pressing upon our Agents the necessity of getting
our farmers located centrally; of making a plan of the Reserve, laying
out a road, say, east and west and one north and south, and requiring
all beginners to settle along those roads before they could get any
assistance from the Department. There is not any question that if a
policy of this kind could be adopted and followed, our Farming In-
structors would have no ground to ask for gasoline and oil. They could
easily cover their territory and visit the Indians three or four times
more often than they do now, with less mileage. We would also make a
saving of thousands of dollars in machinery repairs, and reduce our
medical expenses greatly.

I would recommend that the Department give serious consideration
to the matter of having all Agents draw up such a plan for all their Re-
serves, requiring all beginners to build their homes in accordance with
that plan, and forbidding assistance to anyone who did not comply with it.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Dept' of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,
REGINA, SASK., April 20, 1939.

Attention: Mr. R. A. Hoey.

Dear Sir:

Re: $900.00 Appropriation for Basement & Repairs,
Little Pine Day School, Battleford Agency.

We have the same problem at both Little Pine and Red Pheasant Day School—lack of space for properly carrying on the work. We have outstanding teachers in both schools, and I think the problem at Red Pheasant is more acute than at Little Pine. We are, however, faced at Red Pheasant with the problem of water. There is at present no water supply and where the school is located, it would be very difficult to secure it.

I have discussed with the teacher and Mr. Macdonald the possibility of securing a water supply, and they inform me that it could be secured about half a mile from the present location, and the suggestion has been made that the present school be moved to a location one-half mile away. The ground is very rolling at its present location and it is practically impossible to get a playground. We are also faced with the problem of either increasing the school in size or erecting another building for a second room and an additional teacher if all the children of the Reserve are to be accommodated.

I have asked Mr. Macdonald for a report on the cost of moving the school and putting in a full basement. Pending the receipt of this report, I have asked them to take no further action with regard to the basement of the Little Pine School, and immediately upon receipt of this report I will submit it. I trust the Department will approve of my action in this matter.

I might add that the Little Pine School was enlarged some years ago, and the school and the children's dining room are both 16 feet longer than at Red Pheasant School, while the attendance at Red Pheasant is now larger than at Little Pine, and it will open next Fall with 45 or 50 children. An addition of at least 10 feet should be added to the Red Pheasant School to accommodate the children, as well as a full basement.

Yours truly,

Re: Repairs at Little Pine and Red Pheasant Indian Day Schools

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 23rd instant, in which you intimate that in your judgment repairs at the Red Pheasant School are more urgently needed than the repairs for which provision was made at the Little Pine School.

I note with interest your reference to the site of the Red Pheasant School and the advisability of having this school established on a more suitable location. If the present site is unsuitable, I hesitate to proceed with repairs until the condition is remedied. I have been wondering if it would not be advisable to proceed with the repairs at the Little Pine School this year, on the understanding that a fully modern school with full basement accommodation would be built to take the place of the Red Pheasant School next year. If the new school were built during the holiday season, a certain amount of the lumber at the present school could no doubt be utilized. However, if you consider the present site is reasonably suitable, I can see no serious objection to the expenditure of money on the Red Pheasant rather than the Little Pine School. I shall be glad to have an expression of opinion from you, with respect to this matter, just as soon as you can conveniently send it forward.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

Ref: Your #105-6-5 of May 31st, Repairs to Little Pine & Red Pheasant Indian Day Schools.

With regard to Red Pheasant, the location of this school is not ideal, first in that the ground is rolling and does not lend itself to a good playground, and second, the water situation. We have, however, a fairly good teacher's residence that cannot be moved, consequently the building of a school on another location would mean also the building of a new teacher's residence. The playground situation could be remedied at not much expense by levelling off the ground, and, as stated in a previous letter, a well was dug to a depth of 30 feet when they struck a large rock and had to discontinue. There is, however, a certain amount of water in the present well. It is not a sufficient supply, but is, I think, a fairly good indication that water could be obtained at a little greater depth.

As pointed out in a previous letter, there will be at least 50—probably 55—children wanting to attend this school at the opening of the next session. The extending of the school 20 feet, with a full basement, would accommodate these, but when it was done, we would have a very poor school. I would therefore recommend that your suggestion be adopted, that is, that the school be left as it is this season, and a modern school erected next summer.

With regard to using some of the lumber of the old school for the new, there is no doubt a certain amount of it could be used. I would, however, suggest that the old building be left standing and used as a community hall and workshop. We have an outstanding teacher on this Reserve, who........

Dr. Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Regina.

Re School Situation on Red Pheasant
and Stoney Reserves.

Dr. Robertson,

I should like to outline in more or less detail the school situation on these two reserves.

With the arrival of the new Agent and the opening of the 1938-40 school year, I should like to be able to enforce the rule, that all children of school age, unless physically unfit, attend school regularly, either here or at a residential school, as stated in the Indian Act.

Up to the beginning of this year I was able to keep up a fair average attendance by personal contact and by explaining the requirements of the Indian Act. Then one family, Catholics, whose girl had been in poor attendance, withdrew their child and refused to send her. The school at Delmas would not take her. I reported this to the Office, and in January the father was threatened with court action unless the child attended here. I have reported that this child has not yet attended but no action has yet been taken.

Since this has taken place, another family whose attendance was poor has grown worse; the driver very frequently reports that they are asleep when he leaves the village. These are both Stoney families.

I feel that these two cases should be cleared up in order to correct the attitude of indifference to the school, which has not entirely disappeared and which was evidently very prevalent on these reserves two or three years ago.

When I took over here there was no information at all as the number of children of school age on the reserves. I have made a survey of this point and now think I have fairly good information on this point.
It appears that some of the children have not attended school upon reaching school age, seven years. They have waited until nine or ten, with the result that I have pupils of twelve and thirteen in grades one and two.

At present there are 17 Stoneys on the roll. These are picked up from the Stoney village by a driver throughout the year. About 3 miles west of the Stoney village there is a group of Stoneys as shown in the accompanying sketch. Last year I advised that those of school age in this group be sent to residential school. They, however, do not wish to send them to residential school and they have not the horse power to bring them to this school and to carry on their other work. Would it be possible to provide a driver for this group? He would serve 16 children (as per sketch). A driver would certainly be more economical than residential school grants. This driver might be paid $2 per day, and the driver from the village $1 per day. (Up to now the driver from the village has always received $2 per day, but an extra driver would shorten his route). This is advising an extra expense of $200 per annum to serve 16 children.

On the Red Pheasant Reserve, I have 25 on the roll. These attended fairly well while the driver was on during the winter months, December to April inclusive. Two of these, fairly bright little girls of about 8, have missed five months schooling this year because they live about 4 1/2 miles from the school. These people are Catholics, fairly good workers and farmers. They are willing to send their children here, but we cannot make them, because the children are under 12 and they live more than 2 1/2 miles from the school. Next year there will be two more in the same situation. Would it not be more economical to retain the driver for the whole year at a cost of $200, than to send these four to residential school at a cost of about $600?

May I point out that I am suggesting these extra driving facilities for those children whom we cannot force to attend here, and as being more economical than sending them to residential school.

Mr. Macdonald has told me that he has recommended that an assistant teacher be provided for this school. With an assistant and the proposed 20 ft addition, together with a full basement, I think we shall be able to get along nicely.

There are now 42 on the roll. If my suggestions regarding drivers are carried out, I estimate next year's enrolment as 58.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir,

I reply to your letter No. 302-11 of the 4th inst. regarding the situation at Red Pheasant Day School, falls to me as Mr. Morgan has gone on a well deserved holiday.

It is noted that an adequate Day School building is to be erected on Red Pheasant Reserve to serve both the reserves next year. The school population of which is, at present 55 not counting those now attending Residential Schools at Union Lake and Delmas. It is essential that this new building be such as to provide for two teachers doing vocational training as well as the ordinary Saskatchewan school work. For the accommodation of those now presenting themselves for the fall term it would be necessary to use the dining room as a school room with an additional teacher. If this is not done it will mean refusing admission to about 15 pupils and make the reserves an excellent recruiting field for the Press Gangs from the Residential Schools. We all feel and think you agree, that the Day School reserves should not be sending any pupils away for tuition.

It can be pointed out that the provision of a second teacher at the minimum salary would be less of a financial burden than providing for these pupils in a residential school. There is no need to stress the value of the reserve of a school under Mr. Morgan as compared with the alternate.

Regarding the school vans for Stoney pupils this is well covered in Mr. Morgan's letter of late and it is my opinion that this plan be followed, that is that two vans be allowed, one man receiving $1.00 per school day, and the other with the longer trips being paid $2.00 per day. It is the only method by which regular attendance of the students can be maintained and the parents are constant in their request for this plan. The added cost of $1.00 per day over the plan now operating is more than justified.

It is therefore requested please that these suggestions be strongly presented to Mr. Hoey at an early date.

Should not the estimates now being prepared include an amount for the new school? What amount would you suggest?

Dr. T. Robertson,
Yours truly,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Re: Red Pheasant School, Battleford Agency.

On my recent visit to Battleford I discussed with Mr. Macdonald (at that time Agent); Mr. Morgan, the teacher; and Dr. Lewis, our Medical Officer, conditions on that Reserve. As you are aware, consideration was given to enlarging the present school this season, but the plan was abandoned on your suggestion that a modern school be erected there next season.

The situation confronting us on this Reserve at the present time is that, aside from the children now attending residential schools from that Reserve, there will be 55 children who will want to attend day school this coming session. Our present school will accommodate 40 at the outside, thus 15 will either have to be left without a school or will have to be sent to a residential school.

Mr. Morgan suggested that an additional teacher be engaged and the room now used as a dining room be used this winter as an additional classroom. He also suggested that in that case, an additional driver be secured at cost of $200.00.

As Mr. Ostrander has taken over the Agency, I referred the matter to him for a report and am now in receipt of his report, in which he recommends the suggestions made by the teacher, Mr. Morgan, that an additional teacher be provided and that a two-room school be erected next season. I do not know whether funds will allow this additional expense this season, but if so, I would recommend that the additional teacher be provided, as well as the $200.00 for an extra driver.

In support of this recommendation I would point out that in Mr. Morgan we have an outstanding teacher, not only in classroom work but....

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.
work but also in manual training and work of that kind. He does not spare himself in his work. In addition to carrying on school work and manual training he also has, during the winter months, a night school for the older people. Mrs. Morgan is also deeply interested in the work and is very active in carrying on the work among the women.

I would therefore like to see a two-room school established on this Reserve under the management of Mr. Morgan, as I believe it would be in the best interests of both the Indians themselves and the Department.

I am attaching Mr. Morgan's and Mr. Ostrander's letters on this matter. I might further add that the Indians' homes on this Reserve are scattered all over the Reserve. I have drawn the attention of Mr. Ostrander and Mr. Morgan and our Farming Instructor to the necessity of carrying on among these Indians similar propaganda & that we are carrying on on other Reserves, pointing out to them the necessity of the Indians building more centrally in order that they may receive better medical attention and better supervision on the part of the Farming Instructor and reduce the cost of their implements by shorter hauls. We are also further introducing this idea by refusing to assist young Indians who are just establishing themselves in agriculture unless they build within a reasonable distance of the Farming Instructor and the school.

I might also add that I am sure the prospects are that the school population will continue to increase rather than decline.

Dear Sir,

In the past $5.00 per month has been allowed for hauling water to the Red Pheasant Indian Day School and Residence. When this amount was authorized the average attendance was about twenty-two pupils, requiring about eight barrels a month. The attendance has now considerably increased and about twelve barrels of water is required.

Would the Department consider increasing the amount allowed for hauling water to Seven Dollars a month?

Yours Truly,

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Mines and Resources,
Indian Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa,
March 20, 1940.

EXD.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 5th instant the Department is not prepared at the present time to increase the amount allowed for hauling water to the Red Pheasant School.

While I am unable to state definitely at the present time I may say that it is hoped to be able to provide funds in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1940-41 for the erection of a new school on this Reserve. In that event it might be possible to erect the school where water could be obtained.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir,

I have to advise you that the water supply for the Red Pheasant Indian Day School is far from satisfactory. At present it is costing the Department $5.00 per month.

It appears to me that there is now no chance of having a new School Building erected on the Red Pheasant for a number of years; would it be possible to have another well sunk at a cost of $2.50 per foot including labour and material?

There is a well close to the school showing a little water in at thirty-five, though on account of a very large stone it is impossible to go any further. I would suggest that a new well be sunk close to the well showing water, though I would not guarantee obtaining a good supply at thirty-five feet. However, if we did get a good flow it would be cheaper in the long run than paying out $5.00 per month indefinitely. There are quite a number of dry holes around the school grounds.

Yours truly,

J.P.B. Ostrander.

Memorandum to:

Mr. F.C.C. Lynch,
Chief, Bureau of
Geology and Topography,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

The Director, Indian Affairs Branch, states that the question of digging a well at the Indian day school on the Red Pheasant Indian Reserve is under consideration and asks for any available information regarding underground water conditions in this section.

We have records of 19 wells in nearby areas; four of these sunk to 110 feet failed to obtain water; three others obtained limited supplies, two from depths of 75 feet and one from a depth of 22 feet; the remaining 12 obtained fair supplies of water at various depths ranging from 12 feet to 80 feet.

In the area of which the Indian Reserve is a part most wells sunk in the unconsolidated deposits strike water if continued deep enough. The depth at which water will be found varies from place to place and cannot be foretold. Though water may be obtained at a depth of 38 feet or less one should be prepared to sink to a depth of 80 feet or more.

(sgd.) G.A. Young,
Chief Geologist,

Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter of the 4th instant, No. 105-6-5, in connection with vouchers for attempting to procure a water supply at the Red Pheasant Day School, I am returning vouchers herewith and would ask that they be paid as submitted. I have not forwarded a receipt from Mr. Annear, to the effect that he and his man were given meals by Mr. Morgan for the period stated, but will be able to do so with some considerable expense and trouble, if the Department can not accept the word of myself and Mr. Morgan that the meals were supplied. I might say that the men were fed for more than 18 days, as shown in the voucher, and that Mr. Annear's team of horses, necessary for the job, were also fed from Mr. Morgan's own feed supply, there being no other feed available. However, as I could not keep the amount due Mr. Annear lower than $64.00, Mr. Morgan agreed to accept $36.00 for his payment, having been instructed by me, before the work started, that he must not allow the cost to exceed $100.00.

It is true that the price for digging is altogether different from that mentioned in my letter of the 24th August, but I did not explain this fact as I thought the reason for the change would be obvious. I was quoting on a finished well, with a supply of water and cribbed. It is obvious that we would not want to waste cribbing on a dry hole. The other reason for the difference is in the fact that, to protect the Department's interests, I arranged with this man that he would be paid only 50¢ a foot for a dry hole. It was then necessary to furnish board, otherwise he would have been working for practically nothing. He was certainly underpaid at $64.00, having been on the job a month with a man, a team of horses and a well-machine, for $64.00 and board.

Yours truly,

J.B. Ostrander,
Indian Agent.

at a council summoned for the purpose, according to the rules of the Band, and held on the said Reserve, this 18th day of November, A.D. 1940, in the presence of the Indian Agent for the said Reserve, representing thereat the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs for the Dominion of Canada;

Do hereby, for ourselves, and on behalf of the Indian owners of the said Reserve, request that a sum not exceeding $800.00, Dollars, be paid out of money standing to the credit of this Band, for the purpose of pay $2.00 per school day for the whole school term, for transportation of children of our Band to the Day School at Red Pheasant Res., totalling $360.00 per annum. Dear Sir:

I am enclosing, herewith, resolution signed by the Chief and Council of the Stoney Band for an amount of $800.00 to be expended from their Band funds, for the purpose of paying for transportation of their children to the Red Pheasant Day School and for sinking wells at the necessary points on their reserve.

In explanation I have to say that the homes on the Stoney Reserve are mostly poor, but there are some good homes built on the reserve at the farthest point from the Red Pheasant Day School. The result of this has been that the Indians who wish to have their children attend the day school, live in hovels in an Indian village near the school in the winter. Conditions in these hovels are very bad and the sanitation about the village, in the winter, is terrible, consequently I have discouraged the Indians collecting in the village. To improve matters, I have had the Indians vote money from their funds for the necessary transportation for their children, in order that they may remain in their homes during the winter, mostly a distance of about six miles from the school. They decided that they should pay two dollars per school day, for this transportation and one of their men will take care of it.

The wells are necessary at a number of the homes, where we are trying to encourage the living conditions improved, and that the cattle be increased. This can only be done by permanent water supplies at the homes. The cost of the wells will be about $2.00 per foot, including cribbing and the amount of $440.00 which they have voted should be sufficient for four or five wells. We need this many at the least.

I would be glad to have authority for the expenditures indicated, as soon as possible.

Yours truly,

J.F.B. Ostrander,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

I have for acknowledgment your letter No. 105-65 of the 3rd inst., wherein you ask for further information regarding recent request from the Stoney Band to expend $360.00 in addition to the amount authorized in your letter of September 5th, 1940 for transportation of children to the Red Pheasant Indian Day School.

Most of these Indians live in very poor houses. A number also move in for the winter months leaving very good homes, this habit I am discouraging as much as possible. These Indians live from two to four miles away from the Village; as already informed the Band is willing that $360.00 be charged to their Band Funds, though not for the amount authorized in your letter of September 5th. Knowing home conditions in what is known as the Village, if we can hold the Indians in their good homes it will be money well spent.

re School Heating.

The above school is heated by a four-foot cast-iron box stove placed approximately in the centre of the room. This stove is without protection of any kind.

During cold weather it is difficult to keep the school warm, as it is too hot near the stove and cold near the walls. I think that if we could procure a galvanized tin guard for this stove, about 3' x 5' and 30" high, raised off the floor about six inches, it would tend to cause a current of air, drawing the cold air off the floor, which at all times is very cold, and so bringing about a better distribution of heat in the building.

Yours truly,

E.A. Morgan

Dear Sir,

As the grant for transportation of Stoney Reserve children to the Red Pheasant Indian Day School, payable out of public funds expired March 31st, 1942. Will you please refer to your letter No. 105-6-5 dated January 21st, 1941, wherein authority was approved to the amount of $360.00 for the transportation of children to school payable out of Band Funds.

Will it be in order to continue transportation of children until the end of school term June 1942, chargeable to Mosquito Band Account No. 332?

Yours truly,

J.P.B.Ostrander,

The Secretary,

Ottawa, Ontario,

EX'D

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of April 13th last regarding the transportation of Stoney Reserve children to the Red Pheasant Indian Day School.

In this connection I would refer you to your letter of December 16th last wherein you requested authority to pay the transportation for the period from January 5th to March 31, 1948. Why was authority not requested from January 5th to the end of the term, and further why was authority requested for the expenditure of $360.00 when it would appear that the average monthly expenditure is $40.00, and only three months remain in the term.

Yours truly,

D. J. Allan,
Superintendent, Reserves & Trusts.

J.F.B. Ostendar, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, Indian Agent, Battleford, Sask.

The Bishop of Saskatoon requested Reverend Canon H.E. Hives to communicate with us regarding the nomination of a teacher for the Red Pheasant School. I am just in receipt of his letter and he has a qualified teacher in view. As soon as a definite nomination is received you will be further advised.

I am writing to you at this time in connection with the following statement made in Reverend Canon Hives' letter:

"The school building is heated only with great difficulty and the children from Red Pheasant find the excuse of a cold school during the winter a reasonable excuse for non-attendance."

We do not appear to have received any report from you in this connection and it would be appreciated if you would let me know if the facts are as stated by Canon Hives and, if so, what action can be taken to overcome this difficulty.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
43-302.
Battleford, Saskatchewan, June 19th, 1944.

M. Christianson, Esq., General Superintendent of Indian Agencies, Regina.

With reference to your letter of the 16th inst., I would like to discuss in connection with the question of the continuation of the Red Pheasant Day School. I should point out that the attendance at this school is not as favourable as the figures on the returns would indicate. A large part of the attendance in the last quarter was made up of children of the Union Lake Anglican Residential School who were simply in the day school "marking time" until the residential school should be reopened after the fire. There are, at the present time, six children attending fairly regularly; the number would be about ten if we supplied transportation for some who are living too far away to be able to walk.

I would feel inclined to re-open this school for the next term if we had the right kind of a teacher, and the decision in this regard should rest with the church authorities and the responsibility be theirs to get the right kind or we should not re-open the school. If there was a man and wife at this school, and transportation provided, it would be worth while continuing, in the event of course that the church authorities realize the kind of man and wife needed and appoint no other kind. The last teacher was hopeless and her last term at that school was, in my opinion, so much wasted money. If the church authorities can do no better than that at the present time I certainly think the school should remain closed until something better is available.

The department should be reminded that this class-room building is not fit for use in cold weather and was to have been replaced, but replacement fell through as the result of the war and the matter is in abeyance until the war is over. Doctor Robertson condemned the building in 1938 and arrangements were made to build one in 1939 but the war intervened and I was told that nothing further was done until after the war. The result was that most of the children who were available for a day school were sent away to residential schools and there are now very few available. This should be one of the projects for immediately after the war and, coupled with the building of the school, there should be adequate transportation facilities because some of the families who will have children over.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

With reference to your letter of the 23rd instant, 105-6-5, in connection with the proposed appointment of a new teacher at the Red Pheasant Day School, and in particular to that part which refers to the question of the heating facilities in the classroom, I have to say that nothing has been reported in recent years about this heating difficulty, for the reason that the building was condemned by the late Doctor Robertson in 1938 and arrangements made, at that time, for the erection of a new school to replace this one.

Having been informed that, as the result of the war and the resulting cancellation of all the Department's building programs, no school could be built at this point until after the war, I have not troubled the Department further with complaining about a situation which could not be remedied, and the teachers have been told, when taking over this school, that the heating of the classroom is a problem in the cold weather. I had asked Canon Hives to keep this in mind when talking to a new prospective teacher because I did not want a new one to go there and then start complaining about the heating of the classroom when nothing could be done about it.

I may say that, following my recommendation, in my letter of the 30th May, last, that the school be closed, the Department referred the matter to Mr. Christianson, and he took it up with me again; in reply to his letter, and in order to make the picture more clear to him, I mentioned the matter of the heating of the classroom building. I am enclosing a copy of this letter.

J.F.B.Ostrander,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, September 7, 1944.

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, Indian Agent, Battleford, Sask.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of August 28, in which you submit additional information with respect to the condition of the Red Pheasant Day School.

In this connection I am sending forward herewith copy of a letter received by this Branch from Canon Hives. It is unnecessary to state that the information that Mr. Ross was not prepared to accept the position of teacher at this school was very disturbing to the officials here and to myself.

In view of the fact that we have no definite information with respect to the date on which the Government is likely to undertake a building program, would it be possible to have certain repairs undertaken at this particular school that would enable us to keep it open and in operation for a year or two? It would be appreciated if you would express an opinion on the desirability of banking up the school on the outside and repairing the windows and doors in such a way that heat might be conserved and draughts avoided. You might also express an opinion with respect to the size of the stove now at the school. If, however, you feel that this particular school is beyond repair, you should state so in your letter. In sending forward your recommendations, would it be possible to state, approximately, the total cost?

Encl.

R. A. Hosy,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I am in receipt of your letter of the 7th instant, 105-6-5, in connection with the Red Pheasant Day School. I have noted, also, the contents of the letter which the Department received from Canon Hives in this regard.

Mrs. McDonald, the last teacher, made no effort to keep the dwelling house and grounds in shape and, when she left, I did not spend any money on the grounds or house because I expected that they would not be used any more and such an expenditure would then have been wasted. There is no water supply at the present school site and many wells have been sunk without getting water, consequently the water for the use of the school has been hauled in barrels and it was my intention to make sure of a water supply before deciding upon the site of the proposed new school.

Only six children are now available for attendance at this school unless we are prepared to put on two teams to transport the children to school; in the event that two teams are taking them to school regularly, the attendance would be about fifteen. The additional children would be collected, for the most part, on the Stoney Reserve.

It should be mentioned that Mr. Ross' reason for not accepting the Red Pheasant School, was chiefly the result of his wife's attitude towards it. He had been teacher at the Sandy Lake Indian Day School and, according to his wife's statement, made in my presence, they left that school because it was too quiet and hard on her "nerves". I understand that this school is well equipped and in good condition. It is certainly quiet around the Red Pheasant School and when I heard Mrs. Ross' remarks I made no effort to persuade them to stay as I do not like dealing with "nervy" women. There is the mid-day meal, sewing, etc., for the teacher's wife to help with, and steady nerves would be needed.

With regard to repairing the class-room building, and making it fit for use in cold weather, I strongly recommend (that nothing -
that nothing be done in this connection at the present time. I have not made full enquiry as to the cost because there are no workmen, either carpenters or plumbers, available to give me an estimate and there is little possibility of being able to purchase the necessary materials if we did get the workmen. These matters were not obstacles when the late Doctor Robertson made the decision that it was unwise to spend any money on this old building, but they are obstacles now. The cost of transportation will be considerably higher, if resumed at this time. It was being done for $2.00 a day for each man and team. Present wages are about $8.00 to $9.00 a day for a man and team. There is no water at the school and this would have to be hauled, which would cost at least $10.00 a month; considerably more than this if the teacher was not very careful in using the water.

In addition to all the reasons mentioned, I do not like to think that the expenditure of a large sum of money, at this time, to repair a building for which we may not be able to get a teacher suitable, would mean that we would have to continue the use of a patched-up building, with no water supply, for years to come, instead of having a good building where there is a good supply of water and I know that the Department would not consider the erection of a new building shortly after having spent a considerable sum on the old one.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, September 18, 1944.

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, Indian Agent, Battleford, Sask.

Re: Red Pheasant Day School.

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 11th instant and to thank you for the information contained therein.

In view of all the circumstances, I am disposed to think that this school should remain closed, for the time being at least, but that a new school for the Red Pheasant Reserve should be included in the Government's immediate post-war building program and should be one of the first schools erected. In the meantime and until the new school is established, you might make an investigation with respect to the best site that might be selected, keeping in mind central location, adequate water supply and such matters.

Replying to your letter No. 195-6-1 of the 7th inst., in connection with reopening Red Pheasant Indian Day School. Before any work is done repairing this school, I would suggest that Canon Hives have Mr. P.G. Kehler go out to Red Pheasant Reserve and size up the situation to see if he would be satisfied with conditions there. Canon Hives is absent from Battleford on holidays, and will be away for two weeks. About a year ago a teacher who was interested went out, when he saw the layout he would not consider staying.

There are thirteen children of Red Pheasant Reserve, living 3-6 miles, and fifteen children from the Stoney Reserve living 3-6 miles away from the school who should attend.

If school was reopened transportation would have to be provided for children coming from the Stoney Reserve, two outfits would have to be provided at a cost of $3.00 per day, as on account of the location of the homes to the school, it would be out of the question for one outfit to handle all pupils. Indians of the Stoney Reserve would not consider doing the work for less.

Water is quite a question for school and residence, which has to be hauled a considerable distance.

Enclosed requisition for material and labour will cover requirements to put buildings in fair shape until such time funds are available to erect a new school in a more central location.

Unless the church authorities can obtain the services of a first class teacher, I would not be in favour of reopening school.

Recently, I had an occasion to visit the Red Pheasant Day School which was re-opened this past month with Mr. Adam Cuthand in charge. I found nineteen Red Pheasant children and one child from the Stoney Reserve in attendance.

Construction of One-room Day School and Attached Teacherage - Red Pheasant.

We have now a stock of blueprints, specifications and bills of materials for our standard one-room day school and attached teacher's residence.

The Auditor General has insisted that, in future, the clauses of the Public Works Act with regard to advertising for tenders be adhered to. During the emergency war years, some variations from these regulations were permitted, but we are now required to advertise for tenders on construction of public buildings in excess of $5,000.00. Attached hereto please find a sample advertisement. It is our intention to advertise for tenders for the construction of the Red Pheasant Day School in the near future. Therefore, we would request you to advise us:

(a) The names of the newspapers in or near your agency in which you would recommend that we advertise;

(b) Post offices and other government buildings in which we should display drawings, specifications, etc.

Naturally, your own office will be one in which we will display drawings, etc. If no tenders are received after advertising, you will be advised so that other means can be considered whereby the construction of this school can be carried out during the fiscal year 1948-49. These other means

...... involve
involve:

1. Direct approach to contractors when advertising has failed to produce tenders.

2. Construction on a day labour basis.

3. The erection of a prefabricated school.

With regard to (2) above, the Department, as previously stated, has a complete bill of materials for the construction of this standard school. Other agents have successfully had this school constructed this year by employing a foreman-carpenter and Indian helpers. The drawings and specifications are very clear and the Department buys all the necessary materials. I give you this information so that you can consider such a mode of construction if advertising fails.

We would appreciate receiving from you the information required in paras (a) and (b) above. We should also be advised as to the availability of hydro and water facilities and their distance from the school building.

Bernard V. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Red Pheasant Indian Day School

Reference your 127-105 of February 10 -

In view of the information contained in your above letter, the primary consideration before beginning construction of this school will be the location of a suitable water supply.

In view of our past experience with the location of Indian day schools, it is felt that a most important feature is an adequate water supply. Therefore, you are requested to contact local well drillers and to submit a tender for the sinking of a well which will provide an adequate supply for such a school. Red Pheasant School:

Mr. Capt. Bell took me to this school this afternoon.

Replacement of this school is not in my opinion—and Mr. Bell and Canon Harris concur—an immediate necessity.

Admittedly the school building needs some repairs, but as it stands, it is in better condition than Thunderchild School.

If a new school is to be erected in this area it might rather be on the neighbouring Mosquito (Stone) Reserve from which children have for part of the year been transported to Red Pheasant School.

The chief factor in re-siting the school seems to be the desire to get a good well. But on the Red Pheasant Reserve a bountious well is difficult to assure.

It is worthwhile trying to find water near the existing school. And so, with the advice of Mr. Wm. Cockburn (Mr. Bell's assistant) who was in the party, I have suggested that a shallow trial hole be dug at a spot about 70 yards south-east of the school. The tree growth and contours of the land suggest that the chances of finding water here are as good as in most places. The shallow hole is to be dug...
to discover whether a certain type of clay is present near the surface. If such clay is found up, it would indicate that a shallow well would be useless, and actual boring operations would be tried elsewhere. You are aware that a limit has been placed upon the depth and cost of well-boring operations.

A decision as to the site for boring (or not boring at the spot suggested) is expected by the end of this week.

I think the Department should repair this school, make a determined search for water, and transport the Stony children throughout the coming school year. Meanwhile the future needs of the Stony reserve are being studied.

Costs involved:
- Transportation $600
- Well $430
- Repairs $470 (?)

Repairs:
1. Block up basement windows and holes between wood and top of foundation. "Hear is cold!"—no wonder!
2. Remove some siding from outer wall, insulate, and re-nail siding which was taken off.
3. Trade stove for the one in lunch-room which is in better condition.
4. Possibly tar roof.

Ottawa, August 31, 1948.

Memorandum: DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Red Pheasant Indian Day School, Battleford Indian Agency, Province of Saskatchewan.

It has been proposed to erect a new school to replace the present Red Pheasant School, but it has not been found possible to obtain the services of a contractor. In the meantime, Major Clark of this Division visited the school and on his return recommended that instead of building a new school, we repair the present building and in his opinion, if certain repairs are made, the building will be suitable for several years.

Mr. N.C. Anderson, Battleford, Saskatchewan, is prepared to repair the roof, insulate the interior of the building and also repair the foundation and basement and repair the porches, at a total cost of $1,060.00 for material and labour.

Superintendent Bell considers that this quotation is reasonable and we would appreciate it if the Minister would approve the acceptance of Mr. Anderson's tender.

Director.
August 31, 1948.

Mr. C.S. Bell,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency,
Battleford, Sask.

We have your letter of the 23rd instant enclosing estimates of Mr. Anderson for renovating and repairing the Red Pheasant Indian Day School.

We are submitting Mr. Anderson's tender to the Minister for his approval. As soon as this is obtained, you will be advised.

The floor registers should not be removed but only covered thinly in case the furnace is later renovated. If you consider that fuel can be more economically provided for a 50" drum heater than for the 42" heater, the Department would be prepared to authorize the purchase of the former. You might let me know at what price the larger heater can be secured.

Would there be any trade-in allowance on the old stove and if not, what disposal do you consider could be made of it?

The information that we have received from Mr. Clark indicates that one of the toilets, at least, should be repaired.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Education

We were not very fortunate in the operation of the Red Pheasant Day School, of the Battleford Agency, during the present term. The school was opened at the beginning of the term with an unsatisfactory teacher who eventually fractured her hip, resulting in the school being closed for a time. It has recently re-opened with a new teacher, whose services are promising for the future. The water supply at the Red Pheasant Day School is still unsatisfactory, and I do not know when the problem will be solved. Certainly I am not in favour of large further expenditures on the building at the present site unless we can find a satisfactory water supply.

(Sgd) J. P. B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

EXTRACT from Report of His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan, dated Ottawa, October 9, 1924, regarding Indian Schools in Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta, within the Diocese of Saskatchewan.

DIVIDED MISSIONS:

Where the missions are divided between the Church of England and the Roman Catholic, as in the case of "Pine Bluff," where two-fifths are Roman Catholic and three-fifths are Church of England, and in "Pelican Narrows," where three-fifths are Roman Catholic and two-fifths are Church of England, I would suggest as a solution of the problem in these and similar cases, that the Department should provide a proper stipend for a fully qualified teacher, together with an allowance for house, and divide that total amount between each Church pro rata. If either Church declines to conduct a qualified school, then the whole sum should go to the one willing to do so under, of course, the Conscience Clauses. We of the Church of England have our own school at Pine Bluff and Pelican Narrows.

Right Reverend Sir:

Dear Mr. [Name],

I have a very good man available at the end of this month highly qualified as a teacher, single and of good spirit and presence, with Saskatchewan certificate, if an arrangement can be made with the Department to give the major part of the year to school work at Pine Bluff and the minor part to Pelican Narrows.

Of course I know that the Roman Catholics have the school at Pine Bluff at present but as I have already pointed out to you the injustice of that arrangement when the Church of England has the majority of the pupils.

I have already suggested that in that case, so as to be fair to the Roman Catholics we should be given a pro rata stipend and maintenance and keep the school open only for that part of the year when the Indians are there, i.e., from 7 to 8 months.

DAY SCHOOL AT PELICAN NARROWS

On August 14th, I visited and inspected a day school at Pelican Narrows. The children are Anglicans who belong to Peter Ballendine's Band and the school is open for the summer months only.

With reference to establishing ten months' schools at Stanley and Pelican Narrows, Saskatchewan, we understand that the Department's Agents have decided that the three months' schools are not a success.

Re "Pelican Narrows" School, the Indians have decided that Sandy Narrows would be a better site for the school than Pelican Narrows. They would leave their children there during the Winter and provide fish and wild meat as at Stanley. They were disappointed at not having a school last summer, but are pleased now at the thought of having a ten months' school.

There is no school building or teacher's residence at either Pelican or Sandy Narrows. When the summer school was held, the Church building was used for a school and the teacher lived either in a tent or in an Indian house. New buildings would therefore be needed at Sandy Narrows and all school equipment and supplies. Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter 132-5-1, dated the 31st ultimo, in connection with previous correspondence from myself and the Rt. Rev. W. Burd, in connection with establishing a school at Pelican Narrows.

The letter I received from the Rt. Rev. W. Burd was something similar to the one directed to the Department.

It is not quite clear to me just what Bishop Burd has in mind. I take it that he wants a school established at Pelican Narrows to be open the whole year around, also he wants accommodation provided for the children so that they can be boarded while the parents are away on the trapping grounds. He states the Indians would lend two houses for the accommodation of the boys and girls and two women would keep house, also that the men would help provide food by supplying meat and fish and also put up wood. I presume that he is looking to the Department to provide the other food that would be necessary and also pay the other expenses of upkeep. In fact what he is asking for is a kind of Boarding School.

I do not think his idea would be practicable. The Indians no doubt have promised to supply fish, meat and wood, but getting them to keep that promise so that the children would be well supplied with these articles mentioned would indeed be a difficult matter. It would ultimately mean that the Department would have to provide for the entire upkeep of the school and children, including food, clothing, upkeep of building and payment of staff. Then again I would not think it would be wise to leave school children in charge of Indian women who were not their parents.

This matter of opening a school at Pelican Narrows has been taken up before. I would refer you to my letter dated Aug. 19th, 1937, which was in answer to your letter 132-5-1, dated March 15th, 1937. I am inclined to stick to the recommendations made in that letter.
The building I referred to in my letter of Aug. 19th, 1937, can, I believe, still be got. Of course we can build a new log school and the Indians could get out the logs. It would be best to figure on paying for the work, otherwise it would be difficult to get it done. The necessary lumber and other building materials would have to be taken in from Flinflon and it could only be done during the winter months. The freight rate from Flinflon to Pelican Narrows is $3.00 per cwt.

If you intend taking any action with regard to providing a school at Pelican Narrows, it should be taken right away, as it is impossible to get material into Pelican Narrows after December or early in January, as the transportation companies make their trips about that time. I do not think they would make a special trip and if they did it would be at a much greater price than that I have quoted. I believe a suitable building would cost the Department $1500.00

Your obedient servant,

My Dear Mr. Hoey:

I believe the time has arrived for me to write to you and remind you of the half-yearly amount due from the Department 'in lieu of rent' for St. Alban's College building, Prince Albert. You will be pleased to know that as far as I am able to ascertain everything is flourishing at this school. I was there two Sundays ago, and the children seemed very happy and contented, and well fed and clothed.

While writing I wonder if this is the time to ask if the Department has any plans regarding buildings at Pelican Narrows. Our school teacher last summer worked under many and great difficulties, both with regards to the school building and also the teacher's residence. I am quite sure that your representative, Mr. Bowman of The Pas, will be able to tell you just what conditions are at this point. I know personally that many visitors, who were there this summer have been very outspoken about the lack of accommodation. I do not wish to bother you about conditions in Northern Saskatchewan, but in view of the report sent to me by our teacher, I thought I should inquire from you as to whether any building programme was contemplated.

I was sorry not to be able to be present when the deputation from our Church met with the Minister and yourself and others some two weeks ago, but it was impossible for me to get away at that time. With kindest personal regards,

Dear Bishop Martin:

Now that the first signs of spring are visible here in Ottawa, our thoughts are turning to the re-opening of our seasonal schools. One of these is the Pelican Narrows School, where Mr. Halkett taught last year. You will recall that last November you enquired concerning improvements at this seasonal school, and I wish to advise you that the following action has been taken:

(a) Thirty students' desks, one teacher's desk and one teacher's chair have all been ordered and are now on their way in to Chief Simon Linklater at Pelican Narrows by tractor train. These desks cost $560.00 F.O.B. Flin Flon, Manitoba.

(b) In addition, we have authorized Inspector Hamilton to purchase 20 sacks of lime, 7 double sash windows, 6 rolls of heavy kraft building paper and nails, to be sent in to Chief Linklater.

(c) We have authorized Mr. Agent Bowman to expend $30.00 for the necessary labour in making these repairs.

(d) We are ordering a stock of standard school supplies for forwarding to Mr. Bowman, so that these can be sent in when the teacher is ready.

We would appreciate it, therefore, if you would consider the nomination of a teacher for this school. It is hoped that we can obtain a university student who either has had some experience in teaching or who is now studying Education at university. However, I am aware of your keen interest in the education of these northern Indians and
realise that you will have someone in mind to carry out this important work.

Sincerely yours,
