I wrote to Bishop Martin concerning the closing of both these schools, as I indicated to you in my letter of May 4. I have now received a reply from him reading as follows:

"Thank you for your letter of May 4th, regarding Stanley Indian Day School and Pelican Narrows Indian Day School.

"I was greatly disturbed to read your suggestion of not opening the school at Stanley this year and I do hope that this suggestion will not be carried into effect. Stanley is one of the oldest Christianized areas in Northern Saskatchewan and the people there have been very loyal both to their country and to their church; and they are among the clearest and happiest Indians I know. I fully agree that last year's records are most discouraging, but there is, I suggest, a definite reason for this poor showing. Before I left for England last May a Mr. H. Smith was appointed teacher at Stanley. Unfortunately, Mr. Smith suffered a nervous relapse and left Stanley rather hurriedly. Mr. Smith is a veteran of the last war and, I understand, he went through very nerve racking experiences. But I am fully persuaded that with a good teacher there this summer these children will receive some elements of education whereas now many of them are..."
receiving none at all. We have had a day school here for many years even when the Residential School was situated at Lac la Ronge, and as a matter of fact some ten years ago the school was not a seasonal school but was open all the year round. The church has gone to considerable trouble and expense to keep this school open even to the extent of begging the loan of buildings to house the teacher, and I do hope that this school may be kept open.

"Regarding Pelican Narrows, again our need here is very urgent and I have often wondered why your local officials have not taken steps to meet the situation here. I am still in communication with Mr. Heathcote and I wrote to him a few days ago. He is willing to go to Pelican Narrows if we can arrange some assistance towards his travelling expenses. I hope we may be able to secure the services of this young man because he is definitely interested in the Indians. It seems very difficult to secure help from our Western young men simply because they say they can earn much more money working in other fields.

"I have visited the North frequently and I have seen both these schools in action and I would say most definitely and emphatically that they are both fulfilling a very important function in the life of these wards of the Canadian Government. I am planning to visit both Stanley and Pelican Narrows at the end of next month and I do hope I shall not be compelled to face the disappointment of these loyal Indians in not having teachers for their children. I do hope I may have another opportunity of discussing this matter with Major MacKay and you because I believe I have facts regarding this situation which would persuade you to see the necessity and importance of doing everything possible to further Day Schools at both Stanley and Pelican Narrows."

Bernard F. Henry,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Mrs. Johnston:

You will recall that in my letter of October 19, I advised you that I would write to you further with regard to the resolution sent me in your letter of October 5.

With regard to Deschambault Lake, unfortunately this is not an Indian reserve. The present Indian Act states quite clearly (Section 9 (a)) that Day Schools can be established on Indian reserves only. I understand that 13 children from this area are now enrolled at the Lac la Ronge Residential School in Prince Albert.

At Pelican Narrows we of course have been operating a seasonal school. Our records show that in 1947 the attendance was as follows:

| Quarterly Report | Enrollment | Average Attendance |
|------------------|------------|--------------------|
| June 1947        | 26         | 7                  |
| September 1947   | 27         | 10                 |

We have not the complete figures for the 1946 summer's attendance as yet. However, I think you will agree with me that the 1947 average attendance was certainly very low, considering the number of children who were enrolled at this school. At several other points across Canada we have converted seasonal schools into full-time day schools when the Indian pupils attended regularly. At Pelican Narrows the school attendance, particularly in 1947, seems to have been unsatisfactory.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Henry,
Superintendent of Education.

Pelican Narrows School Supplies

On July 12, the teacher A. Hallett wrote to Bishop Martin to say that supplies had not arrived. The Bishop's letters to The Pas received no answer as the Agent was in hospital and the clerk absent on treaty money trips. The Bishop didn't know the circumstances. Pencils and scribblers had to be bought at the local H.B. post. (The post at Norway House sold 589 scribblers locally last year!)

In April of this year I relayed by telegram the Bishop's request that these seasonal schools be supplied on time. It might be better to send the parcel to Mr. Lovell as planes operate frequently from The Pas or Flin Flon.

OTTAWA, Dec. 20th, 1922.

Reverend Sir,

Referring to official letter of July 10th last, with reference to the New School at Round Plain, I beg to say that the Indian Agent has forwarded a return for the period this School was open between August 21st and September 30th last.

This return showed that the School was conducted for 30 days between the above dates. As the Department's regulations require that Indian Day Schools be in operation for 200 days in the School year, in order to draw the full salary, we are allowing for the period this School was in operation up to September 30th, 20/200 of $600.00 or $90.00.

A cheque for the above amount is being drawn in favour of the Treasurer of the Presbyterian Church in Canada, and sent to you.

Your obedient servant,

Leask, Sask.
February 27th, 1931.

Sir,

I have been advised that the United Church Treasurer at Toronto, has not yet received cheque covering Rev. J.G. Meek's salary for quarter ended December 31st, 1930 as teacher of the Sioux Wahpton Reserve No. 94A Day School. Will you please advise me reason of delay?

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

John Weir
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa. March 4th, 1931.

Sir,-

With reference to your S-50 of the 27th ultimo regarding the December quarter salary of Rev. J. G. Meek, teacher of the Round Plain School, I beg to say that cheque in payment of his salary was forwarded to the treasurer of the United Church of Canada, Toronto, on January 14th, last. I am communicating with this gentleman today.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

John Weir, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Leask, Sask.
Ottawa, March 4th, 1951.

Reverend Sir,

Under cover of a letter dated the 27th ultimo, Mr. Indian Agent Weir, Leask, Sask., states that he has been advised from your office that you have not received cheque covering the December quarter salary of Rev. G.J. Meek, teacher of the Round Plain School, (Wahpaton Sioux Reserve). Cheque #7025, for $180., in payment of Rev. Mr. Meek's salary for the quarter ended December 31st, 1950, was forwarded to your office on January 14th, last. This cheque has been returned to the Finance Department and shows that it was cashed at the Canadian Bank of Commerce, Toronto, on January 19th, last, and bears the stamp of the United Church of Canada.

I trust the above information will permit you to trace the cheque in your books and arrange for payment of the amount due Mr. Meek.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. Robt. B. Cochrane, D. D.,
299 Queen Street West,
Toronto 2, Ont.

Ottawa, April 26, 1938.

Dear Sir:

We have just received the March quarter return of the Round Plain Combined School.

The Department has no record of having received the return for the quarter ended December 31, 1937. Was the school in operation during that quarter? If so, the usual return should be sent at once. Please let me hear from you in this matter, as we are not paying the March quarter salary until we ascertain whether or not it will be necessary to also pay salary for the December quarter.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

H. S. Davis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Leask, Sask.
May 14th, 1936.

Mr. R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

My dear Mr. Hoey:

RE: ROUND PLAIN SCHOOL

We have received neither the December quarter nor the March quarter grant for the Round Plain School, Prince Albert. In view of the letter received today, I can understand the delay in sending at least part of the March quarter but I am at a loss to know why we did not get the December quarter. Mr. Meek has been asking us about it. Of course we have advanced the money to Mr. Meek but it is a little inconvenient for us to have the Government six months behind with their cheque when you are behind three months in so many others. We understand that all the reports from Mr. Meek were sent in good time to the Agency at Leask and their receipt has been acknowledged.

Believe me,

Very sincerely yours,

RBC:HC

Their church are building a very nice residence for the teacher on the Reserve, and have requested me to move the present School building close by.

Dear Mr. McDonald:

As suggested by you I am submitting herewith a list of the minimum requirements of school equipment and supplies for the Indian children on the Round Plain Reserve.

1. Seats: Our Department requires that only single-adjustable desks and seats be purchased. I would strongly recommend that the Moulthrop or chair desk be purchased. The new Normal School at Saskatoon is equipped throughout with these, carried by the E.N. Moyer Co. They will be found to be most satisfactory in cases where the building is to be used for purposes other than school on occasion. 7 of the small is needed and 7 of the medium size.

2. Blackboard: 120 sq. ft. of Hyloplate blackboard is required. This must be 4 feet wide.

3. Books: Our Department supply free Readers. These will probably be all the texts that the Indian children will require this year.

4. Dictionary, globe, and maps. If the Indian Department will purchase the first two mentioned, the trustees of the adjoining district should supply the maps, which I believe they will do. A suspended globe is the most satisfactory, 12 inches in diameter is the minimum size.

5. I would suggest likewise, that the expense of the teacher's chair and desk and the cupboard be shared by the Indian Department and the local trustees.

6. The Indian children will require 2 washbasins, individual cups and towels, and soap.

7. In the modern school the pupils make considerable use of the blackboard so that a supply of white and colored chalk is needed.

8. I should think that about 8 dozen scribblers and 6 dozen lead pencils would be sufficient for this year.

9. Hand work and seat work material will be required. This will be necessarily forwarded as a supplementary list by the teacher, as the amount and nature of this material can be determined only as the teacher sees the need.

Yours faithfully,

signed— J.T. Tomlinson.

OTTAWA, May 11th, 1922.

Sir,

The Department has received through the Rev. J. H. Eadie, General Secretary, Board of Home Missions of the Presbyterian Church, Toronto, a list of the school equipment and supplies for the use of the Indian children who will attend the combined school which it is proposed to establish on the Round Plain Reserve. This list of equipment was prepared by Mr. J. T. Tomlinson, one of the Provincial Inspectors of Schools for the Province of Saskatchewan.

Regarding the desks, the Inspector recommends that the Moulthrop or chair desk be purchased, and requests that 14 of these be supplied for the Indian children, I may say that we have never supplied these desks to any of our Indian schools. They are a very expensive type of desk and are hardly required for Indian children. The type of desk we usually supply is the single school desk, and consider that this type would be more suitable for this school. However, I will be pleased if you will ascertain the type of desk that is to be supplied for the white children, as it will be necessary, in order to have uniformity in the classroom, that we supply the same type of desk. You should also state the number of Indian children who will likely attend, as we are responsible for the supplying of the desks for the Indian children only. You should furnish full shipping directions, also the name of the person and the address to which the desks should be shipped. We will place the order here as soon as full information is received. Kindly reply, giving the information asked for as soon as possible.

The Inspector has suggested that the cost of a teacher's desk, chair and cupboard be shared between the Department and the local trustees. We will be prepared to pay half the cost of these furnishings upon receipt of certified vouchers from you for the amount of the Department's share. You can ascertain the cost of these supplies from the white trustees and advise the Department.

As soon as we hear from you, we will place the order for the desks.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.
